Project_Title: Advanced Technology for Improving the Design Basis of Offshore Wind Energy Systems
Awardee: Savannah River National Laboratory (operated by Savannah River Nuclear Solutions, LLC)
FOA_Name: U.S. Offshore Wind: Removing Market Barriers FOA
Project_Description: Savannah River National Laboratory developed a dynamically coupled met-ocean model from open source models of the atmosphere, waves, and ocean using a software coupling tool to simulate two hurricanes in the South Atlantic between Cape Hatteras, NC and West Palm Beach, FL. Savannah River prepared maps of engineering parameters related to hurricanes and modeled wave loads on monopile offshore wind turbine foundations. For more information, see Proceedings from AWEA Offshore Windpower Conference & Exhibition 2013.

Project_Title: Testing Facilities and Capabilities at the National Wind Technology Center
Project_Description: The National Renewable Energy Laboratory's (NREL's) National Wind Technology Center (NWTC) conducts research across a complete spectrum of applicable wind energy engineering disciplines, including atmospheric fluid mechanics and aerodynamics; dynamics, structures, and fatigue; power systems and electronics; and wind turbine engineering applications. The purpose and objective of this project is for the NWTC to maintain mission readiness and operational expertise of DOE’s specialized research facilities and capabilities at the NWTC. The safe operation and continued reliable performance of all NWTC site activities are dependent on the work conducted under this project. It includes maintaining highly skilled staff and advanced, state-of-the-art research methods, facilities, and capabilities needed to support evolving DOE and industry research needs. It also includes acquisition of research data and development of data processing and analysis tools. These competencies enable validation of early-stage research projects.

Project_Title: Testing Partnerships
Project_Description: The main purpose of the testing facilities and capabilities at the National Wind Technology Center (NWTC) at the National Renewable Energy Laboratory (NREL) is to operate and maintain custom-developed infrastructure tailored to provide research validation testing and demonstrate new technology for energy independence, energy security, jobs, and rural economic development. This included enabling safe and efficient proof-of-concept research testing to extremes, and designing experiments that anticipated test article failures. The NWTC supports research testing with skilled workers, qualified operators, and technical experts. The NWTC also provides high-caliber research-grade instrumentation and measurements to enable model validation and ensure systems meet required standards. This allows industry partners to focus on their technology innovations, not testing requirements (e.g., experiment design, safety procedures, and data acquisition).

Project_Title: Testing Facilities and Capabilities at Sandia: Field Test Facilities - DOE Turbine Facilities and Test Sites O&M including Scaled Wind Farm Technology Facility (SWiFT)
Project_Description:
The purpose of the Scaled Wind Farm Technology (SWiFT) facility is to provide the United States with world-class test capabilities for conducting innovative wind turbine and wind plant research & development. The site is strategically located in Lubbock, Texas, a region with a high wind resource and low turbulence, which is ideal for research. The SWiFT facility is the only open-source wind plant in the world. SWiFT’s unique testing capabilities are derived from three key features: the turbines, the layout, and the wind resource. These features, combined with staff knowledge and skill, result in a test facility well-suited for investigation of wind turbine wake behavior, turbine-to-turbine interaction, wind plant technologies, rotor system innovation, uncertainty quantification, and computational tool validation. 
SWiFT project objectives include 1) keeping operations running safely and smoothly by continuously implementing Sandia’s Integrated Safety Management System and Work Planning & Control practices, 2) keeping equipment in good working order through maintenance activities, and 3) providing operational support to WETO projects and other users of the facility to achieve their test objectives. 
In addition to supporting research in energy security and energy independence, SWiFT supports job creation, infrastructure enhancement, and rural economic development in its location of Texas Tech University, Lubbock, TX. Partners include Vestas Wind Systems, Texas Tech University, Group NIRE, Windar Photonics, Micron Optics, GE Renewables – Onshore Wind, Pentalum, Skyspecs, DTU, University of Texas Dallas, NREL, LM Wind Power, Siemens Wind Power, ABB, National Instruments, Binational Industrial Research and Development Foundation, DOE Advanced Manufacturing Office, and DOE Small Business Vouchers.

Project_Title: Distributed Wind Research, Development, and Testing: Competitiveness Improvement Project, Market Assessment, Soft Costs Analysis and Reduction, Resource Assessment, and Technology Support
State: WA; OR; CO; KS; OK; GA; MN; NY; ME; VT; NH
Project_Description: Distributed wind (DW) refers to the use of wind power as a distributed energy resource, where wind energy technologies (big and small) are connected directly to the electricity distribution grid, on the customer side of the meter, or at an off-grid location to support local loads or grid operations. Deployed by individuals, businesses, communities, and electric utilities, distributed wind refers to any size wind turbine or small array of turbines that generates power for local or on-site use. Relative to utility-scale wind and other distributed energy resources such as photovoltaics, market growth for DW systems has been hindered by outdated and untested technologies; high hardware costs; inaccurate resource and performance assessment; high non-hardware balance-of-system costs; and an unclear understanding of the DW market pathways and potential opportunities. The purpose of this project is to drive innovation in wind technologies designed for distributed energy applications and develop a fundamental understanding of the market opportunity for planning a more robust portfolio to support DW cost reduction and market development. Primary project objectives include 1) reducing DW system LCOE and 2) increasing the number of small and medium scale wind technologies tested to nation standards for certification. A component of this task is the Competitiveness Improvement Project, which is an annual competitive solicitation concentrating on turbine testing, advanced manufacturing, and system optimization for small and medium size wind turbine technology. DOE has awarded CIP funding to 28 subcontracts to 15 companies in six rounds of funding; awardees include Bergey Windpower, Endurance Wind Power, Intergrid, Northern Power Systems, Pecos Wind Power, Pika Energy, Primus Windpower, Rock Concrete, Sonsight, Star Wind Turbines, Urban Green Energy, Ventera Wind, Wetzel Engineering, Windurance, and Xzeres. For more information, see the CIP factsheet. Secondary project objectives include, 1) developing an understanding of the gaps in site and performance assessment, 2) developing an understanding of the market opportunity for different scales of DW systems, 3) developing a costs benchmark to measure the impact of R&D opportunities, and 4) develop an understanding of the needs of installers and project developers.

Project_Title: Distributed Market Wind Research (Market Report)
Project_Description: This project provides distributed wind market research, data, and analysis to support DOE's research and development activities. These activities are intended to increase distributed wind’s cost effectiveness and performance, reduce hardware costs, and increase the number of certified small and medium wind turbines. Read more in the Benchmarking U.S. Small Wind Costs. The annual Distributed Wind Market Report is the main product of PNNL’s research, data collection, and analysis and is one part of DOE’s WETO distributed wind portfolio. The objective of the portfolio work is to enable wind technologies as distributed energy resources to contribute maximum economic and system benefit to energy systems now and in the future. To that end, theDistributed Wind Market Reportanalyzes distributed wind projects of all sizes and details within the U.S. small wind market. By providing a comprehensive overview of the distributed wind market, this report can help guide future investments and decisions by industry, utilities, federal and state agencies, and other interested parties. PNNL also has the opportunity to leverage its distributed wind expertise to educate federal agency stakeholders about distributed wind and the importance of using proven technology. Renewable energy, including distributed wind, is already being pursued by many federal agencies, but with mixed results. Education and outreach to these agencies helps facilitate a cohesive approach to distributed wind across the federal government. Educating federal agencies about distributed wind will enable them to make better decisions and reinforce the message that PNNL and WETO are available to help with distributed wind questions.

Project_Title: A2e: Measurement, Testing, and Verification: Field Study Design and Analysis (Complex Flow/WFIP Support)
Program_Area: Atmosphere to electrons: Plant Optimization and Resource Characterization
Project_Description:
The Wind Forecast Improvement Project in Complex Terrain (WFIP 2) had two overarching scientific goals:
  • To improve the physical understanding of atmospheric processes that directly affect wind energy forecasts in areas of complex terrain.
  • To incorporate the new understanding into foundational weather forecasting models in order to improve wind energy forecasts. In support of these goals, the participants in WFIP 2 conducted a field campaign to assess how physical processes over a broad range of spatial scales alter wind speeds across the rotor diameter.
From this research, the team worked to develop physical modeling methods and atmospheric theories that could be incorporated in foundational weather models to improve wind forecasting. The results of implemented changes were evaluated through assessment of the improvement in forecast skill and the economic impact of these improvements. Finally a set of decision support tools were developed to facilitate the operational use of improved forecasts. The overall design for WFIP 2 in the complex terrain of the Columbia Gorge focused on a set of weather phenomena that posed particular challenges for wind and wind power forecasting: frontal passages with stable mix-out; gap flows; convective outflows; mountain waves; topographic wakes; and marine pushes. In addition to these specific phenomena, the Columbia Gorge area posed amplified challenges in general for numerical weather prediction models owing to the moderately complex terrain of the Columbia Basin of eastern Washington and Oregon and to the highly complex terrain of the Cascade Mountains just to the west. The improvement of our ability to characterize and forecast winds affected by these phenomena was expected to in turn improve the forecasts of wind energy and thus lowered its overall cost. Moreover, by focusing on underlying physics, the forecast model improvements in WFIP 2 were expected to be generally transferable to other regions of the country, providing a broad benefit to wind power generation in the U.S. As the FOA awardee for WFIP 2, Vaisala proposed a comprehensive program of observations, model improvement, and development of decision support tools focused on a field campaign in the Columbia Gorge. DOE also provided support to ANL, LLNL, NREL, and PNNL as well as NOAA to provide additional scientific contributions to this study.

Project_Title: A2e: High-fidelity Modeling and Validation: Uncertainty Quantification and Sensitivity Analysis
Program_Area: Atmosphere to electrons: Plant Optimization and Resource Characterization
Project_Description: This was a sub-project of the Wind Forecast Improvement Project. Many of the forecast errors made by regional models, such as the Weather Research and Forecasting Model (WRF), resulted from errors in approximations (or parameterizations) of physical processes that were too small or brief to be resolved by the model. Because there are many such approximations in all atmospheric models, it was generally difficult to identify which ones were the largest contributors to model uncertainty. Alternatively, it was possible that there were systematic shortcomings in the parameterizations themselves—such as implicit assumptions related to the complexity of the terrain. The method of uncertainty quantification (UQ) was used to systematically quantify the sensitivities of the wind outputs of interest (e.g., speed, direction, shear, wind power, temperature, and surface fluxes of heat and moisture) to various input parameters.

Project_Title: Mesoscale-Microscale Coupling - Model Development & Validation
Program_Area: Atmosphere to electrons: Plant Optimization and Resource Characterization
Project_Description:
Atmospheric flow drives the structures in wind plants, thus forming the atmospheric energetics that we seek to harvest from the wind. Resolving this mesoscale weather phenomenology thus directly impacts wind plant performance. This complex problem requires coupling those mesoscale phenomena to the flow in the wind plant itself. Modeling these phenomena requires the combined expertise of atmospheric physicists, numerical simulation experts, and wind plant subject matter experts to formulate the tools needed to optimize turbine and plant design. Resolving the critical flow structures impacting performance and codifying these effects into design and performance prediction tools is the goal of the Mesoscale to Microscale Coupling program. This program is based on requests from industry for research that will result in new tools for designing and optimizing their future wind plants. Hence several national laboratories have combined critical resources to resolve this difficult challenge. The overall goal of the Mesoscale to Microscale Coupling team is to build new high-performance-computing-based multiscale wind plant simulation tools that couple a broad range of scales. The scale interactions enable the optimization needed to ensure the efficient, reliable production and integration of future wind-generated electricity. Specific objectives include:
  • Establish a validation framework with well-defined performance metrics, and apply it to benchmark wind-plant simulation cases.
  • Improve the current state-of-the-science of coupling mesoscale information into high-fidelity HPC-based wind-plant simulations to reduce error in predicting wind speed and turbulence characteristics.
  • Disseminate methods with stakeholders.
  • Verify and Validate results using formal and reproducible techniques.
  • Quantify the uncertainty in the results.

Project_Title: Wind Turbine – Radar Interference Mitigation R&D
Project_Description:
This project follows from the DOE co-funded 2011-2013 Interagency Field Test & Evaluation (IFT&E) program co-led by MIT Lincoln Laboratory and Sandia National Laboratories. This effort is aimed at solving deployment barriers for wind energy systems by developing and evaluating mitigation methods that reduce or eliminate the adverse effect of wind turbines on radar systems. Wind turbines can affect radar systems used for missions in defense, aviation safety, and weather forecasting. The work plan is aligned with the three themes outlined in DOE’s Federal Interagency Wind Turbine Radar Interference Mitigation Strategy:
  • improving the capacity of government and industry to evaluate the impacts of existing and planned wind energy installations on sensitive radar systems;
  • developing and facilitating the deployment of mitigation solutions to increase the resilience of existing radar systems to wind turbines;
  • encouraging the development of next-generation radar systems to be resistant to wind turbine interference.
This effort produces high-impact research and development aimed at eliminating wind turbine radar interference as an impact to critical radar missions, ensuring the long-term resilience of radar operations in the presence of wind turbines, and removing radar interference as an impediment to future wind energy development. For more information on work the U.S. Department of Energy and its national labs have done to minimize the effects of wind turbines on radar, see Wind Turbine Radar Interference Mitigation Factsheet. Also, see the Federal Interagency Strategy for more information.

Project_Title: High-Fidelity Modeling
Program_Area: Atmosphere to electrons: Plant Optimization and Resource Characterization
Project_Description:
The goals of the High-Fidelity Modeling (HFM) project, which are also at the core of the Atmosphere to Electrons (A2e) initiative, are to reduce wind plant losses and to drive significant reductions in the cost of wind energy through dramatic improvement in the understanding of the fundamental flow physics and structural dynamics governing whole wind plant performance, including wake formation, complex terrain impacts, and turbine-turbine interactions. An overarching objective of this project, which is a close collaboration between NREL and Sandia National Laboratories, is to create an open-source computational-fluid-dynamics and computational-structural-dynamics software suite that is well suited to high-fidelity petascale wind farm simulations on leadership-class DOE high performance computing (HPC) facilities. Predictive, physics-based high-fidelity computational models, validated with targeted experiments, provide an efficacious path to understanding wind plant physics and reducing wind plant losses. Simulations will span from the atmospheric boundary layer (under relevant stability condition configurations), its interaction with the wind plant (down to and including turbine-turbine interactions), the response of individual turbines, and the impact of complex terrain. These simulations will directly influence the blade, turbine, and wind plant design process by providing a validated “ground truth” foundation for improving computer-aided engineering tools allowing for technology innovations (e.g., new physics-based engineering models created through better understanding and guided by HFM simulations). The longer-term target beneficiary of this work is the broader wind community, including OEMs, developers, plant owner/operators, universities, and national laboratories. While the focus of our HFM and simulation environment is on very large DOE HPC systems, the software developed will certainly benefit the broader wind community and be usable on the HPC clusters owned and used within the wind industry. Most important will be the new technology that evolves from a better understanding of the plant flow physics and the ability to rapidly assess innovations with respect to full-plant performance. Specific outcomes include:
  • Create the next generation of predictive and physics-based computational simulation tools for wind plants and turbines that seamlessly scale on DOE HPC assets.
  • Reduce wind cost of energy by providing the simulation and knowledge foundations for the next generation of design tools that will enable and accelerate wind plant layout and turbine optimization, shorten time to market of technology innovations, and greatly increase confidence in predictions of wind plant performance.
  • By performing model development in an open-source community development environment, create simulation capabilities that are self-sustaining, which involves rigorous automated unit and regression testing, a multi-platform build system, and comprehensive up-to-date documentation.
  • Maintain a long-term collaboration between the DOE Wind Program and Office of Science and leverage Office of Science investments in HPC supporting exascale simulations of wind plant flow physics and innovative technology development, and place wind energy computational simulations at the forefront of exascale computing.

Project_Title: Rotor Wake Measurements & Predictions for Validation
Program_Area: Atmosphere to electrons: Plant Optimization and Resource Characterization
Project_Description: The Rotor Wake Measurements and Predictions for Validation project is the experimental validation hub of the DOE Atmosphere to Electrons (A2e) program. Researchers working on this project have provided high-fidelity observations and model validation support for the Advanced Flow Control Science for Wind Plants, High-Fidelity Modeling and Integrated Systems Design and Analysis projects. In this project, researchers have applied a validation and uncertainty quantification framework to perform validation studies using data gathered from existing public data sets. They have also gathered new data sets and performed model validation studies using observations from the Sandia Scaled Wind Farm Technology (SWiFT) facility, NREL’s National Wind Technology Center and the NextEra Energy Peetz Table wind farm. The data includes observations of the atmosphere and turbine interactions within wind plants under both standard operating conditions, as well as those useful for wind farm control. The project includes further development and design of testing facilities at the SWiFT site including the National Rotor Testbed (NRT) rotor. Plans for future testing in full scale wind plants have been made and initial utility scale testing has commenced at the Peetz Table wind farm.

Project_Title: Advanced Flow Control Science for Wind Plants
Program_Area: Atmosphere to electrons: Plant Optimization and Resource Characterization
Project_Description:
Advanced flow control science for wind plant research develops the tools necessary to design and implement control strategies that improve the overall wind plant performance. In particular, this project develops the technical capabilities, methods, and approaches that enable “smart plant” control design to optimize wind plants with respect to energy capture and loads. The project advances wind farm controls-oriented modeling to include advanced wake physics, wake interaction, energy entrainment, and the impact of atmospheric conditions. The advancements in our scientific understanding of wind farm flow physics allows us to deliver new and innovative wind farm control strategies and algorithms that can manipulate underlying physical phenomena driving performance. To demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed control strategies, this project also performs field campaign and large-eddy simulation to quantify the real-world benefits of implementing wind plant level control.    
In addition to plant-level control science, there is a growing interest in offshore wind energy control science. In particular, the design and analysis of offshore floating turbines remains an open research question. Part of this project also addresses the development of controls-oriented models and generic control strategies for offshore floating platforms. Advanced sensing and actuation are investigated to understand the benefits to floating wind turbine performance.

Project_Title: Integrated Systems Design and Analysis
Program_Area: Atmosphere to electrons: Plant Optimization and Resource Characterization
Project_Description:
The overall objective of the Integrated Systems Design and Analysis (ISDA) activity is to develop wind plant design and optimization tools that leverage knowledge from high fidelity modeling (HFM) simulations, experimental test campaigns, and other relevant wind plant R&D. In other words, the ISDA project will take what is learned from HFM and experimental activities and apply that knowledge to improving and optimizing wind plant design strategies and tools. Specifically, the work in this activity will focus on improving ISDA design capability through a better understanding of system dynamics, conducting sensitivity analysis and uncertainty quantification of design tools. This effort will include implementation of new developments in systems engineering best practices and standards into DOE-supported wind farm design and analysis tools.The Systems Engineering & Optimization (SEO) initiative develops an analysis platform and research capability to capture full wind plant system interactions to achieve a better understanding of how to improve system-level performance and achieve system-level cost reductions. The effort incorporates advances in computational algorithms, simulation methods, physics-based improvements, cost, and performance modules to assess new technology opportunities and advance the state of the art and best practices in multidisciplinary design, analysis, and optimization (MDAO). The objectives of ISDA-SEO are to:
  • Integrate wind plant engineering performance and cost software modeling to enable full system analysis
  • Apply a variety of advanced analysis methods in MDAO and related fields to the study of wind plant system performance and cost
  • Develop a common platform and toolset to promote collaborative research and analysis among national laboratories, industry, and academia.

Project_Title: Data Archive & Portal
Program_Area: Atmosphere to electrons: Plant Optimization and Resource Characterization
Project_Description:
The Data Archive and Portal (DAP) focus area, a key capability of the Atmosphere to Electron (A2e) initiative, has been established to disseminate results from the experimental and computational efforts conducted under the A2e initiative for a diverse range of users. The Presidential Executive Order on Open Data Policy Memo M-13-13 is a directive to government agencies to manage information as a strategic asset throughout its life cycle—from creation or collection to disposition—so that, by default, it is open, accessible, and publicly usable while ensuring safeguards to protect individual privacy, confidentiality, and national security (as applicable). To comply with the Order, the DAP was established to:
  • Create an open, easy-to-navigate user interface that facilitates community data access, interaction, and national and international collaboration.
  • Collect, store, and preserve data for all elements and thrust areas of the A2e Initiative; Act as a hub to strongly accelerate and advance model development, testing cycles, and execution of high-fidelity models.
  • Facilitate collaboration by automating labor-intensive tasks, providing intelligent support for complex tasks, and reducing duplication of effort.
  • Enable both observational data and model-based discovery and will include data sets that can be used to validate models.
  • Interact with the integrated wind design plant thrust area to develop and improve reduced order models that will be used as part of systems optimization during the design process.

Project_Title: Performance, Risk, and Uncertainty in Finance (PRUF) - Wind Plant Performance Benchmarking
Program_Area: Atmosphere to electrons: Plant Optimization and Resource Characterization
Project_Description:
The goal of PRUF is to understand and mitigate the associated risks with developing, owning, and operating wind power plants. This requires mapping project finance related uncertainty to identify the major pre-construction risks for investors. PRUF encompasses a wide range of risk reduction activities including performance benchmarking, quantification of performance variability, and operations research. The scope of PRUF includes providing support to related industry working groups, such as the Power Curve Working Group and the Consortium for Advancement of Remote Sensing to help identify the best pathways to reduce uncertainty associated with power curves and resource measurements. The primary focus area of PRUF is the Wind Plant Performance Prediction (WP3) Benchmarking activity, which is a first of its kind data sharing and analysis initiative between major wind industry stakeholders. The WP3 task can have a significant positive near term impact on wind deployment and LCOE—lessons learned through WP3 can rapidly find their way into industry standards and practices, given the close working relationship between project stakeholders. WP3 aggregates energy yield predictions from consultants and provides critical feedback on the accuracy and uncertainty of those predictions. This facilitates greater investor confidence in the predicted outcomes, and therefore reduces risk premiums associated with wind project investment. Because the PRUF team works closely with industry leading consultants to identify modeling deficiencies, WP3 is able to accelerate the adoption of new methods for estimating energy production. There are three project objectives for the benchmark effort that will accomplish the above outcomes:
  • Generate accurate, independent benchmarks of current pre-construction energy assessment accuracy;
  • Improve accuracy and reduce uncertainty in pre-construction energy estimates; and,
  • Create an open knowledge sharing platform that provides state-of-the-art methods and models for pre-construction and operational energy assessments.
Ultimately, WP3 benefits project owners, consultancies, OEMs, and project investors by reducing project risk and enabling greater investment and deployment across the industry.

Project_Title: Performance, Risk, and Uncertainty in Finance (PRUF) - Wind Plant Reliability Benchmarking
Program_Area: Atmosphere to electrons: Plant Optimization and Resource Characterization
Project_Description: There is large uncertainty in the lifetime cost of maintaining and operating wind turbine rotor blades and other components. O&M costs represent approximately 30% of wind LCOE, with maintenance comprising roughly half of that, and large component failures responsible for the majority of maintenance costs. Blades, for example, are designed for a 20-year life while blade replacements affect approximately 1-3% of the fleet per year, and typically cost $200,000 to $300,000 per replacement. The cost of these replacements is spread out over OEMs, owner-operators, and insurance companies, affecting all major components of LCOE. Furthermore, the causes are varied and range from design and manufacturing errors, to transportation and installation damage, to operational damage. The cost of these failures can be only be alleviated by prevention or repair. With a “safe life” design philosophy, components are designed to a certain lifetime based on assumptions about the strength of materials, the quality of the manufacturing process, and the environment that the components will operate in. With a “durability and damage tolerant” design philosophy, effects of defects and damage, inspection technology, repair techniques, and operating environments are known and tightly coupled, such that the current state of the component is continually evaluated. Moving from safe-life to durability-and-damage-tolerant in wind will result in lower cost and cost uncertainty by focusing maintenance effort where and when it is needed, and avoiding large-scale failures, as it has in commercial aerospace. Additionally, the wind industry will soon be facing a large life-extension problem as plants near their original design life. This problem is similar to what commercial aviation faced several decades ago and will likely need this new philosophy to operate turbines reliably and safely for 10 or more additional years. To accomplish this goal, the industry will need to have a validated repertoire of inspection, analysis, and database tools to enable industry participants with the ability to be proactive rather than reactive to address the problems of wind turbine blades with defects. Collection of wind turbine reliability data will allow for high-value investments in the wind industry to lower component failures. These topics together will positively affect all areas of LCOE: capital cost, finance, O&M, and energy production.

Project_Title: DOE Offshore Wind Strategy Support
Project_Description:
In 2011, the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) and U.S. Department of the Interior (DOI) jointly released A National Offshore Wind Strategy: Creating an Offshore Wind Energy Industry in the United States. Over the past 5 years, DOE has achieved most of the stated objectives outlined in this document. In 2015, DOE and DOI began developing a new offshore wind strategy aimed at creating an update to the 2011 plan, but based largely on DOE’s 2015 Wind Vision. DOE requested that the National Renewable Energy Laboratory (NREL) help develop the new strategy, to be released in 2016, by engaging stakeholders in the U.S. offshore wind industry, providing supporting analysis, and working with the DOE strategy team to develop the final strategy document. This activity is part of DOE’s fundamental mission to support the industry by communicating accurate information and analysis about the technology and economic potential of the emerging offshore wind industry. A general framework for the new 2016 U.S. offshore wind strategy was provided by the 2015 Wind Vision, which prescribed 86 gigawatts (GW) of offshore wind energy by 2050. However, the Wind Vision was written at a high level and did not provide the details to be translated directly into an actionable strategy for the DOE program, and did not establish a high-resolution baseline for cost, value, or economic potential. Under this activity, NREL provided direct support to DOE and DOI’s Bureau of Ocean Energy Management by conducting analysis to support the updated offshore wind strategy. This analysis incorporated NREL’s unique capabilities and expertise in offshore wind resource assessment and economic and market analysis to help DOE assess the current situation in offshore wind and chart a course for the next 5 years. NREL also updated existing data and developed new information that will help the creation and maturation of an offshore sector to the wind industry as described in the Wind Vision. The overall project objectives were to Support the development of a new offshore wind strategy in the context of the Wind Vision and to provide analysis and information to the offshore wind strategy team. These analyses included:
  • Creating a terminology framework to translate offshore wind energy into oil and gas language.
  • Updating offshore wind resource potential from the 2010 report.
  • Reporting on the opportunity space for offshore wind in the coastal energy market to 2050.
  • Quantifying the levelized cost of energy (LCOE) for offshore wind on a geospatial plane.
  • Identifying pathways towards achieving cost competitiveness.
  • Building a framework for evaluating economic potential regionally.
  • Identifying non-LCOE value-adders.
The primary output of the project was the publication of technical reports including the 2016 strategy itself. These reports are available on DOE's website.

Project_Title: DOE Offshore Wind Lidar Buoy Deployments
Program_Area: Offshore Wind; Atmosphere to electrons: Plant Optimization and Resource Characterization
Project_Description:
Because of the cost and time to permit, build, and operate an offshore meteorological tower, there have previously been no multi-seasonal hub-height measurements of wind in the continental shelf areas of the United States. This has impeded the wind industry due both to the lack of direct wind observations and to the lack of validation of wind resource modeling offshore. In recent years, wave motion-correcting lidar systems have been demonstrated to be capable of providing wind measurements at hub-heights over the ocean. These instruments, mounted on buoys, are far less costly to procure and deploy than conventional meteorological towers. The purpose of this project is to assist the offshore wind industry by providing previously unavailable hub-height wind and supporting met/ocean data. For example, prior to deployment of DOE’s lidar buoys, there had been limited or no wind and wave resource data in the BOEM designated Wind Energy Areas to allow confident deployment and operation of wind turbines in the offshore environment. Resource assessment data are critical to determining the expected annual energy output from a wind plant as well as proper turbine and plant design. Further, meteorological and oceanographic (metocean) data that are privately obtained for project siting purposes are generally proprietary, which limits further research opportunities and benefits to the wind industry. This project has three primary objectives:
  • Deploy DOE’s lidar buoys either directly in support of DOE projects or through loan or partnership agreements to support the development of offshore wind energy in the United States
  • Analyze data collected by the buoys to validate resource characterization offshore and to gain additional insight into how air-sea interaction physics affect the wind profile
  • Make the data collected and associated analyses publicly available for the benefit of offshore wind energy development in the United States

Project_Title: Modeling and Validation for Offshore Wind
Project_Description:
In 2018, DOE published the Wind Vision 2017 Update study, which emphasizes the need for offshore wind as a critical component for achieving wind deployment and cost goals in the United States. Offshore wind has significant potential to provide power to regions of the country where other sustainable energy sources are not readily available, or where space on land is constrained. While offshore wind costs have been rapidly decreasing on a global basis, innovative and optimized offshore wind technologies have the potential to reduce costs further. Without validated design tools, rapid technology innovation and the resulting cost reduction in the offshore wind industry will not happen. To address the need for validated offshore wind modeling tools, the Offshore Code Comparison, Collaboration, Continued, with Correlation (OC5) was initiated. OC5 is an international research project run under the International Energy Agency (IEA) Wind Task 30, and this U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) task supports NREL’s leadership and participation in the project, as well as a new extension that will run from January 2019 to January 2023, also known as Offshore Code Comparison, Collaboration, Continuation, with Correlation, and unCertainty (OC6). The objectives of the project are to:
  • Validate engineering-level offshore wind modeling tools by comparing simulation results to measurement data from a variety of experimental campaigns of varying structure types and conditions.
  • Develop datasets needed to address specific validation objectives identified as critical to the accurate use of offshore wind modeling tools.
  • Improve the physics of the offshore wind modeling tools to address both the outcomes of validation campaigns and the technology innovations that require the expansion of the tools’ applicability and capabilities (where limitations hinder technology advancement).
  • Identify research and development needs beyond the scope of this project to better understand the physics of offshore wind systems and how to appropriately integrate these attributes into the modeling tools.
  • Establish guidelines on best practices for modeling, testing, and validating the innovative technologies needed to lower offshore wind costs, including how to treat and assess uncertainty in the models and validation process.

Project_Title: Study on the Potential Application of Additive Manufacturing in Wind Turbine Components and Tooling
Project_Description:
The manufacture of large wind turbine components is a time-consuming and labor-intensive process. Blade manufacturing, for example, consists of many manufacturing steps and processes, requiring hundreds of man-hours to produce a single blade. Other turbine components and tooling suffer from the same complexity, cost and time issues. The pressures to reduce costs are extreme when faced with a competitive global energy market and decreasing or expiring wind subsidies. Additive manufacturing (AM) a>or 3D printing, is rapidly evolving as a promising pathway for turbine OEMs to reduce manufacturing costs through reduced part counts, reduced tooling costs, reduced processes, reduced cycle times, increased repeatability, and automated manufacturing lines. It is also being considered as a potential pathway to lower LCOE by enabling larger turbines, unconstrained by logistics, through cost-effective local or onsite manufacturing. Despite AM being used commercially in the aerospace and medical industries there is very limited research advancing the technology in the wind industry due in large part to the extremely large component sizes and thin profit margins. Addressing the value propositions and risks through technoeconomic analysis and actual protype builds and material characterization is of high value to the industry. Initial investigations led to a demonstration project sponsored jointly by WETO and the DOE Advanced Manufacturing Office where a 13m blade mold was fabricated in partnership with TPI Composites using the Big Area Additive Manufacturing Process (BAAM) pioneered by ORNL. Further investigations have led to the identification of potential applications of AM across the wind manufacturing industry, including heat exchangers, electronics packaging, printed magnets, printed concrete towers and even direct blade manufacturing. New sponsored DOE programs and industry CRADAs are aimed at tackling several of these identified components, both in wind energy and other comparable industries. The lessons learned and knowledge gained through the early demonstration project and AM wind study are now being applied to a comparative study for the direct manufacturing of an end use structural nacelle component with partner Vestas. The main objectives of this project are to:
  • Demonstrate the efficacy of AM as a potential advanced manufacturing technology for wind turbine components and tooling;
  • Understand the costs, relative advantages and disadvantages of selected AM approaches in the manufacturing of wind turbine components and tooling.
The core project team consists of: ORNL that is pioneering the development and adoption of a wide range of AM approaches, NREL that has deep expertise in wind turbine technologies as well as technoeconomic analysis, and industry partners with intimate knowledge of the manufacturing demands, practices and costs in the global wind industry.

Project_Title: Wind Turbine Blade Durability and Damage Tolerance
Program_Area: Next-Generation Technology Development and Manufacturing; Atmosphere to electrons: Plant Optimization and Resource Characterization
Project_Description:
The goal of this project is to reduce cost-uncertainty in the manufacturing and operation of wind turbine blades by enabling the transition from a safe-life methodology to a durability-and-damage-tolerance design methodology. This will be accomplished by understanding the effect of manufacturing defects and lightning damage on blade structures, the ability of non-destructive inspection (NDI) technologies to determine the extent of these issues, and the most cost-effective damage repair methods. The impact of this work will be to both lower levelized cost of energy, which directly impacts national energy objectives, as well as to further develop and improve the wind turbine operations and maintenance (O&M) sector. O&M is the fastest growing area of employment in the industry, and the likely source of most future wind jobs. The results of this project will be broadly applicable to the industry, ranging from OEMs and blade manufacturers to owner/operators and service companies. At the conclusion of this project we will:
  • Improve field inspections by assessing the viability of NDI methods to detect in-service damage in wind blades. This knowledge will be transferred to service companies to make NDI more prevalent and more successful at identifying damage. Specifically, this work will develop safer and more cost-effective robot-deployed NDI concepts to expand the inspection capabilities of third-party service companies. One or more of these methods will be selected and used to perform benchtop inspections of specimens with representative, engineered flaws. Based on these results, one NDI method will be integrated into a deployable, proof-of-concept system by collaborating with a robotic crawler company, NDI equipment manufacturer, and wind turbine service company. This proof-of-concept system will be deployed at a wind farm to perform initial field validation test and provide hands-on inspection experience for wind farm operators and service companies.
  • Quantify best methods to repair defects and damage in wind blades. Currently, many blades are scrapped due to lack of acceptable repairs of structural elements. The project builds on previous effects of defects experimental and modeling work to both determine the applicability of standard composite repair methods and seek to develop improvements specific to the wind industry.
  • Integrate blade design, manufacturing, and operation into a lifetime value model. The cost of manufacturing and operating a blade over its lifetime compared to the energy that is captured is vital to understanding potential improvements in both rotor design and operational reliability. As these costs are spread over multiple parties, it has been difficult to fully evaluate the effect that new blade technology has on costs This gap will be addressed through the development of a cradle-to-grave cost vs. revenue model.
  • Understand the effect of lightning strikes on wind blade carbon laminates and the ability of NDI technology to detect the damage. There is uncertainty in the effect of lightning strikes on carbon fiber spars in wind blades. While lighting strikes are not new to wind, carbon blades are becoming more common. A carbon spar blade may show evidence of the strike entering into the carbon material, but how to find and assess the level of damage is not well known. This task will address that issue by subjecting wind blade carbon fiber samples to lightning level currents and performing NDI and mechanical testing on them to determine inspectability and strength degradation.

Project_Title: Wind Turbine Drivetrain Reliability: White-Etching Crack (WEC) Root Cause Analysis
Project_Description:
The objective of the project is to reduce operations and maintenance (O&M) costs related to wind turbine drivetrains. The operational conditions of wind turbines present unique design challenges. Low rotor speeds, large bearing sizes, and variability in load and speed can all lead to detrimental tribological contact conditions in gears and bearings. These conditions lead to accelerated failures, such as bearing axial cracks, micropitting, fretting, and scuffing, that are predominant and responsible for the higher than anticipated drivetrain O&M costs. These types of failure modes are not accounted for in design standards; are not preventable using currently applied design, material, and tribological technologies; are not attributable to quality control; are complex in nature; and are generally independent of specific component suppliers. Current solution approaches developed with limited understanding have led to an inefficient process of field trial and error that has cost the industry significant resources and time. Through this project, drivetrain reliability will be increased by characterizing the mechanisms of the predominant and unaccounted failure modes, such as gearbox planetary or white-etch cracking bearing failures and surface-initiated main shaft bearing failures; developing and validating mitigation solutions for them; and developing accurate life models for improved component design specifications. Turbine availability and energy capture will be increased by developing more effective fleet management tools for drivetrain inspection, monitoring, and remaining useful life (RUL) prediction. The project includes five specific tasks as described below:
  • Planetary section failures, although relatively infrequent, are expensive because they typically require a full gearbox replacement with a large crane. The objective of the first task is to understand the causes of planetary bearing failures related to unequal load sharing and then develop and demonstrate planetary design solutions that provide robust load sharing in the wind turbine application.
  • The most common gearbox failure mode is axial cracks in the raceways of intermediate- and high-speed stage bearings, also called “white-etching cracks” (WECs). WECs cause as much as 71% of the failures and can occur under 20% of the design life. Though they have been reported for over a decade in various industries, the reason for their prevalence in wind turbine gearboxes is not known. The objective of the second task is to characterize the causes of WECs through analysis and testing. Once characterized, appropriate mitigation solutions can be examined—ranging from new bearing materials, coatings, and heat treatments; to improved lubricants; to changes in gearbox designs and to changes in turbine operations.
  • Main-bearing reliability has been identified as a significant O&M cost driver by owners and operators. Unlike the most common gearbox faults, main bearings typically cannot be replaced uptower and require removal of the rotor system with a large, expensive crane. Very little failure mode information exists in the public domain; however, evidence suggests that main-bearing failures are related to progressive wear modes stemming from micropitting, skewing, skidding, or fretting and not from rolling contact fatigue. The objective of the third task is to characterize the causes of main-bearing progressive wear failures through analysis and testing. Once characterized, appropriate mitigation solutions can be examined.
  • The fourth task objective is to enhance wind plant O&M practices through the mining of turbine and plant performance data and to improve condition monitoring (CM) technology. The wind industry is rich with Supervisory Control and Data Acquisition, high-resolution history, and meteorological tower data, plus event or maintenance reports; however, these collectively are not well explored.
  • The fifth task objective is to exchange information, including gearbox failure event data, related to drivetrain reliability among industry and national laboratories. The public drivetrain reliability collaborative helps define the technical tasks and propagates outcomes from the tasks to the industry and standards communities.
For more information, see Investigation of high-speed shaft bearing loads in wind turbine gearboxes through dynamometer testing. In addition, see Gearbox Instrumentation for the Investigation of Bearing Axial Cracking and Comparison of planetary bearing load-sharing characteristics in wind turbine gearboxes Report for supplemental information.

Project_Title: Wind Turbine Drivetrain Reliability
Project_Description: The objective of the wind turbine drivetrain reliability project is to reduce wind plant operations and maintenance (O&M) costs related to drivetrain reliability. Wind plant O&M is a $2B to $3B annual market in the United States, and O&M costs are increasing 5% to 10% per year and will continue to grow as the fleet ages and installed capacity grows. The predominant drivetrain component failure modes are gearbox planetary section bearing failures due to unequal load sharing; and gearbox parallel section bearing failures due to white-etching, cracking, and surface-initiated main shaft bearing failures. They occur prematurely, are not accounted for in design standards, typically are not attributable to quality control, and are independent of specific component suppliers. Identifying the mechanisms of failure through testing and analysis; and validating mitigation approaches to improve the inherent reliability of these bearings will reduce drivetrain O&M costs. O&M costs can be further reduced by developing and verifying diagnostic and prognostic tools to increase operational reliability and turbine availability. Owners and operators are the primary beneficiaries of this project. They report that O&M costs are excessive for existing wind plants to the extent that they reduce the anticipated profitability and thus the development of new wind plants. Wind turbine OEMs and component suppliers would also benefit from this work. The wind turbine drivetrain reliability project includes five specific tasks as described below. The most common wind turbine gearbox failure mode is axial cracks in intermediate and high-speed stage bearings, also called "white-etching cracks" (WECs). These WECs cause as much as 71% of the failures in some populations and can occur within 10% of the gearbox design life. Though these types of cracks have been reported for more than a decade in various industries, the reason for their prevalence in wind turbine gearboxes is not known. Suspected contributing factors include the bearing material, lubricant chemistry, and degradation; stresses and sliding from transient operational conditions, curtailment, and grid events; and stray electrical currents. The objective of the second task is to characterize the causes of WECs in intermediate and high speed shaft bearings through analysis and testing. Once characterized, appropriate mitigation solutions can be examined-ranging from new bearing coatings, to improved lubricants, to changes in gearbox designs, to changes in turbine operations. For more information, see Investigation of high-speed shaft bearing loads in wind turbine gearboxes through dynamometer testing. In addition, see Gearbox Instrumentation for the Investigation of Bearing Axial Cracking and Comparison of planetary bearing load-sharing characteristics in wind turbine gearboxes Report for supplemental information.

Project_Title: U.S.-Sourced, Next Generation Drivetrain for Land-Based and Offshore Wind Turbines
Awardee: National Renewable Energy Laboratory (operated by Alliance for Sustainable Energy, LLC)
Program_Area: Next-Generation Technology Development and Manufacturing; Offshore Wind
FOA_Name: Next-Generation Drivetrain FOA
Project_Description:
The National Renewable Energy Laboratory next-generation drivetrain project optimized and tested a hybrid design that combines the advantages of geared and direct-drive concepts through an improved single-stage gearbox and a medium speed permanent magnet generator that reduces the need for rare earth materials. The technology is expected to improve drivetrain reliability, increase efficiency, and be scalable to 10 megawatts. Advances in wind turbine drivetrain technologies are necessary to reduce the cost of energy for land-based and offshore wind turbines. The geared, medium-speed drivetrain developed for this project combines multiple incremental but important innovations to meet or exceed the goals of producing a lighter, more reliable, and more efficient drivetrain design that decreases installed capital costs, levelized replacement and operations and maintenance costs, and the levelized cost of energy. The objectives for the second phase are:
  • To complete the detailed design, fabrication, and dynamometer testing of a 750-kW drivetrain that includes key gearbox hardware and power-converter software innovations.
  • To complete the design, fabrication, and bench-level testing of medium-voltage hybrid Silicon/Silicon Carbide (Si/SiC) modules.
By successfully completing these technology validation tests, the technology readiness level of each innovation developed by the industry partners will be advanced to level 6, increasing their commercialization potential; and their benefit to the levelized cost of energy (estimated in the first phase of the project) will be demonstrated.

Project_Title: Wind Standards Development
Program_Area: Next-Generation Technology Development and Manufacturing; Testing
Project_Description: The main objective of this project is to guide, actively participate in, and—where logical—lead the development of domestic and international standards. These standards benefit the industry and level the playing field in the market by presenting clear international product design and performance validation requirements. These standards also benefit the end users by ensuring that equipment adheres to the standard, achieves an appropriate level of quality, and, therefore, performs to the expectations of the owners and operators. For example, the work on the Wind Turbine Certification Advisory Committee (WT-CAC) and subsequent IECRE conformity assessment system aims to reach a uniform interpretation and application of the International Electrotechnical Commission (IEC) standards for the purpose of certification, which should result in mutual recognition of test reports and turbine certificates. If accomplished with the right level of quality, this would reduce the need to duplicate efforts and thus also reduce the cost of energy. This conformity assessment system has also developed into a forum in which all industry stakeholders can collaborate and ensure that their needs are met in the conformity assessment requirements.

Project_Title: Grid Systems Operation for Wind: Stochastic Tool Evaluation
Project_Description:
Stochastic programming is frequently mentioned as an important solution to address power grid operations with higher shares of renewable energy, including wind power. However, despite significant research on this topic in recent years, there are still many open questions about what are the most promising application areas as well likely benefits of moving from deterministic to stochastic approaches. In this project, Argonne conducted a detailed assessment of how stochastic approaches can be used at different stages in system and market operations, from day-ahead scheduling to real-time dispatch. The Argonne team first conducted a review of existing work and summarized the main results from previous studies while also identifying the main impediments for introducing stochastic methods into operational decisions making. Next, the team developed a systematic set of metrics and a consistent framework to evaluate different scheduling, dispatch, and market operations strategies. They also conducted an initial quantitative evaluation of the potential benefits of stochastic programming approaches compared to traditional deterministic models and other alternatives. The case study was conducted on a hypothetical test system, considering a number of realistic constraints and operational procedures. The results of this project provided the electric power industry with better insights into the range of different stochastic methods that can be applied to power system operations, the potential benefits of shifting towards stochastic methods in operations, and also to better appreciate likely challenges, from technical, market, and computational perspectives. Overall, the project has expanded the industry’s understanding of potential methods and tools available to address the uncertainty and variability in wind power and other renewable resources, thereby facilitating a more cost effective integration of wind power into the grid. More specifically, the objectives of the project were to:
  • Classify existing approaches and tools for stochastic grid operations under uncertainty in renewable generation.
  • Identify the most promising application areas for stochastic approaches in grid operations, considering cost, reliability, market implementation, and computational perspectives.
  • Identify the main impediments for introducing stochastic methods, considering system operators, utilities, as well as operational software vendors.
  • Refine existing stochastic modeling algorithms and uncertainty quantification methods and development of a simulation framework for consistent comparison of different approaches for grid operations.
  • Quantify potential benefits of stochastic programming applied to day-ahead commitment, intra-day scheduling, and real-time dispatch for a medium-sized test system.
  • Improve the understanding of the potential benefits and challenges of applying stochastic methods in grid operations in the electric power industry.
Ultimately, the project contributed to lower grid integration costs and enabling of a larger penetration of wind power through improved operational strategies with increasing shares of renewable energy.

Project_Title: WindView: An Open Platform for Wind Energy Forecast Visualization
Project_Description:
The overall objective of this project was to create an open-source, free, situational awareness and decision support platform called WindView. The purpose of WindView is to provide grid operators with knowledge on the state and performance of their power system, with an emphasis on wind energy. The focus was on utilizing advanced visualization to display pertinent information of wind farms and wind power forecasts. The finer objectives of WindView were to:
  • Create a more effective way of visually representing wind energy probabilistic forecasts at multiple time horizons, so that operators can make operational decisions with a high degree of confidence about their available wind resource and predicted dynamics on the horizon.
  • Create a single visualization platform for displaying and representing different wind energy forecast information and pertinent wind farm information with a dynamic and interactive map alongside charts, which are updated dynamically to visualize information as chosen by the user. This will allow operators to assess rapidly changing system states due to wind power and help them formulate corrective actions.
  • Create user documentation, including help files and installation guide, to help users download, install and use WindView effectively.
  • Provide ease of use in the WindView interface design. WindView was made with common coding languages in an easy-to-modify structure. Inputting data streams and using WindView is simple and intuitive.
  • Closely collaborate and engage with industry, in particular the Western Area Power Administration Electric Power Training Center, to elicit feedback during WindView’s development in order to ensure a useful production-level WindView.

Project_Title: Market and Reliability Opportunities for Wind on the Bulk Power System
Project_Description: The goal of this project is to create modeling tools and conduct analysis to better understand the impacts of wind generation on the power system while considering market design and market participant strategies. Previous studies have shown that the technical capabilities of the grid are sufficient to integrate high penetrations of wind energy; however, existing market structures and incentives may hinder access to the physical flexibility available among existing and new resources on the grid. This project examines the fundamental question: How does reliability of future power systems vary depending on wholesale electric market designs? Without the ability to represent realistic markets in future models and studies, system operators and regulators will not be able to integrate wind generation efficiently, creating a more difficult and costly transition to a modern electric power system. Therefore, this project took a modeling approach to provide insights into key drivers of wholesale electricity energy, ancillary service, and capacity prices, including resource adequacy level, operating reserve treatment, and price formation rules. The objective of this project is to characterize institutional constraints that impact the costs and reliability of grid operations at both long-term (decadal) and short-term (from hours to minutes and seconds) timescales. To address these challenges, the project team has developed analytical approaches to help analyze potential shortcomings caused by current market structures and identify key drivers to operating a cost-effective and reliable electricity market with high shares of wind power. The project has deployed conventional optimization approaches, as well as behavioral modeling techniques. The project has leveraged relationships with the Electric Power Research Institute (EPRI) and Independent System Operator/Regional Transmission Organizations (ISO/RTOs) to comprehensively analyze the performance of existing markets and reliability requirements as well as potential new rules and standards. Overall, the project improves our understanding of the impact of wind and other zero-marginal cost resources on resource adequacy and revenue sufficiency under a wide range of market design options and revenue sources. For more information, see Marginal Cost Pricing in a World without Perfect Competition: Implications for Electricity Markets with High Shares of Low Marginal Cost Resources.

Project_Title: Multiscale Integration of Control Systems (EMS/DMS/BMS)
Project_Description: This project is part of the Grid Modernization Laboratory Consortium. This project intends to create an integrated grid management framework that will be akin to having an autopilot system for the grid’s interconnected components — from central and distributed energy resources at bulk power systems and distribution systems, to local control systems for energy networks, including building management systems.

Project_Title: Development and Deployment of Multi-Scale Production Cost Models
Project_Description: This project is part of the Grid Modernization Laboratory Consortium. The project will develop the ability to more accurately estimate economic impact of renewables, storage, and other technologies. It will also research scalable methods for deterministic and stochastic production cost modeling, higher resolution grid models, applications of uncertainty quantification, and high performance computing (HPC). New capabilities will be deployed with system planners through workshops.

Project_Title: Grid System Planning For Wind: Concurrent Cooling/Dynamic Line Rating
Project_Description:
One primary goal of rendering today’s transmission grid “smarter” is to optimize and better manage its power transfer capacity in real time. Power transfer capacity is affected by three main elements: stability, voltage limits, and thermal ratings. All three are critical, but thermal ratings represent the greatest opportunity to quickly, reliably, and economically utilize the grid’s true capacity. With the “Smarter Grid,” new solutions have been sought to give operators a better grasp on real-time conditions, allowing them to manage and extend the usefulness of existing transmission infrastructure in a safe and reliable manner. The objective of the Idaho National Laboratory (INL) Wind Program is to:
  • Provide industry a Dynamic Line Rating (DLR) solution that is state of the art as measured by cost, accuracy, and dependability.
  • To enable human operators to make informed decisions.
  • To take appropriate actions without human or system overloading and impacting the reliability of the grid.
In addition to mitigating transmission line congestion to better integrate wind, DLR also offers the opportunity to improve the grid with optimized utilization of transmission lines to relieve congestion in general. As wind-generated energy has become a bigger part of the nation’s energy portfolio, researchers have learned that wind not only turns turbine blades to generate electricity, but can cool transmission lines and increase transfer capabilities significantly, sometimes up to 60%. INL’s DLR development supports Office of Energy Efficiency and Renewable Energy (EERE) and The Wind Energy Technology Office’s goals by informing system planners and grid operators of available transmission capacity, beyond typical Static Line Ratings (SLR). SLRs are based on a fixed set of conservative environmental conditions to establish a limit on the amount of current lines that can safely carry without overheating. Using commercially available weather monitors mounted on industry-informed custom brackets developed by INL in combination with Computational Fluid Dynamics (CFD) enhanced weather analysis and DLR software, INL’s project offers the potential of safely providing line ampacities up to 40% or more above existing SLRs, by using real-time information rather than overly conservative SLR.

Project_Title: Grid System Planning For Wind: Wind Based Transmission Planning Tool Development
Project_Description: This project supports the development of improved grid integration for renewables and increasing the penetration of wind power production. Transmission line ampacity ratings are traditionally limited by conductor thermal capacity, and are defined by a static rating using predetermined environmental conditions. Without accurately measuring environmental conditions and their effects, existing transmission lines can be significantly underutilized. Applying this same logic to the planning and design of new transmission lines will enable developers and owners to use the dynamic nature of environmental conditions to maximize the ratings, albeit static or dynamic. Using a dynamic line rating system to accurately monitor these conditions will lead to improved line ampacity ratings, better knowledge of operational/reliability issues and potentially safer operation of the overall system.
