The project complements the Energy Department’s ongoing Atmosphere to Electrons (A2e) Initiative, which aims to improve wind plant performance by increasing understanding of how wind moves throughout wind farms. The results of the study are documented in the report, Final Technical Report: The Incubation of Next-Generation Radar Technologies to Lower the Cost of Wind Energy. For more information on work the U.S. Department of Energy and its national labs have done to minimize the effects of wind turbines on radar, see Wind Turbine Radar Interference Mitigation Factsheet.

Project_Title: Wind Forecasting Improvement Project in Complex Terrain near the Columbia River Gorge
Program_Area: Atmosphere to electrons: Plant Optimization and Resource Characterization
FOA_Name: Wind Forecasting Improvement Project in Complex Terrain FOA
Project_Description:
Wind Forecasting Improvement Project in Complex Terrain, known as WFIP2, was a four-year multi-institutional field and modeling study integrating industry, academia, NOAA, and DOE national laboratories in an effort to improve wind forecasts in the 0–45 hour ahead time frame. The focus area for the project was the Columbia Basin of the northwest United States, a wind energy region in complex terrain, which poses severe challenges to forecast models.
The overall objective of WFIP2 was to improve short-term wind forecasts by improving model treatment of atmospheric processes in complex terrain. Improvements have already been transferred to NOAA’s High Resolution Rapid Refresh Model, a foundational weather forecast model for the U.S. Wind power forecasters build these forecasts to provide power forecasts for the wind industry.

Project_Title: A Biometric Ultrasonic Whistle for Use as a Bat Deterrent on Wind Turbines
FOA_Name: Bat Impact Minimization Technologies and Field Testing Opportunities FOA
Project_Description:
The University of Massachusetts, Amherst, developed a novel ultrasonic deterrent designed to cover the entire rotor-swept zone of a wind turbine. The deterrent design consisted of a series of ultrasonic pulse generators, or whistles modeled after that of a bat larynx, which responds in a non-linear fashion to small changes in air pressure, allowing for chaotic changes in frequency of sound produced. The whistles were affixed to a wind turbine blade to passively produce ultrasonic sounds mimicking the spectrotemporal patterns of bat echolocation pulses as turbine blades spin, thereby enhancing the bats’ ability to detect, localize and avoid the moving blades. Initial prototype design were followed by an iterative process of modelling, three-dimensional fabrication, and testing to ensure performance over a range of conditions. Factors critical to success included reproduction of key features of bat larynx acoustic behavior in a man-made mechanical device, evaluation of acoustic performance through the use of a pressurized air-line and wind tunnel, and evaluation of deterrent properties on bats in the laboratory and field. Objectives:
  • Derive design parameters for ultrasonic deterrent based on avoidance responses to sounds by at-risk bat species;
  • Design biomimetic model of bat larynx, which reproduces key aspects of ultrasonic behavior. Confirm prototype whistle acoustic behavior in laboratory and wind tunnel;
  • Model and experiment to derive altered designs which display similar behavior, but at altered frequencies. Confirm prototype whistle acoustic behavior in laboratory and wind tunnel;
  • Evaluate bat avoidance response to sound regimes produced by series of prototype whistles, and
  • Test whistle acoustic behavior on small-scale wind turbine.

Project_Title: Texturizing Wind Turbine Towers to Reduce Bat Mortality
FOA_Name: Bat Impact Minimization Technologies and Field Testing Opportunities FOA
Project_Description: The overall goal of this project was to develop a wind turbine tower coating that 1) bats have little or no interest in approaching (i.e., wind turbine towers are not perceived or misperceived to be a resource), 2) can be applied to operational wind turbine towers or incorporated into their manufacturing stage, 3) is economically feasible to produce and apply, and 4) when tested, effectively reduces bat activity, and therefore bat mortality, at operational wind turbines. The hypothesis was that bats are coming into contact with wind turbine towers (and are therefore at risk of entering the rotor swept zone) because they perceive or misperceive the wind turbines to be a resource, then altering the tower surfaces may provide an innovative means of reducing mortality risk that does not entail a loss in power production. Incremental reductions in bat mortality may be especially important in areas where take of threatened or endangered species is possible. Furthermore, depending on how effective this technology is at minimizing bat mortality, the texture treatment may be used as a stand-alone minimization solution or in combination with other solutions. The wind turbine tower coating development and application plan were completed in 2016. Assessing how bats respond to the coating in a controlled flight facility, as well as testing the effectiveness of the tower coating at reducing bat activity, and therefore potentially bat mortality, at operational wind turbines were completed in 2017. TCU's test results at commercial scale turbines were promising but, statistically inconclusive, requiring additional data to draw more rigorous conclusions. For more information, see Texturizing Wind Turbine Towers to Reduce Bat Mortality report.

Project_Title: Mounted Bat Impact Deterrence System
FOA_Name: Bat Impact Minimization Technologies and Field Testing Opportunities FOA
Project_Description: Frontier Wind worked to develop and demonstrate a bat impact deterrence system to reduce the need for operational curtailment, which requires shutting off turbines during peak bat activity periods. A deterrent system that is as effective as curtailment will allow for normal wind farm operations and increased electricity generation compared to curtailment. In 2016, while Frontier completed their final analysis task, major technical issues with the system’s power supply limited their ability to present significant results. In conjunction with the California Energy Commission, Frontier Energy was planning a second field evaluation of their technology in 2017, to complete the research effort from 2016. Despite Frontier Wind working to address those technical issues directly after the 2016 field season, power supply challenges prevented the second year of testing in 2017, and wildfires around the test site in California prevented completion again in 2018. Due to this circumstance, and additional financial challenges, Frontier Wind was unable to continue the last phase of their initial research.

Project_Title: Ultrasonic Bat Deterrent Technology
FOA_Name: Bat Impact Minimization Technologies and Field Testing Opportunities FOA
Project_Description: The project objective was to advance the development and 2016 testing of GE’s bat deterrent system (initially designed and developed in 2012 and tested in 2013 and 2014 at an operating wind farm) with a goal to increase effectiveness to over 50% with broad species applicability. Beginning in 2013, GE and California Ridge Wind Energy (CRWE) began testing their pneumatic deterrent device at an operating wind farm in Illinois. Prior research had demonstrated the effectiveness of GE’s commercial-grade, air-powered, ultrasonic bat deterrent to be between 30% and 50% depending upon bat species. Additionally, the research supported by this program provided insights into bat behavior and ultrasonic deterrent design that had not previously been explored, specifically bat behavioral responses in the presence of ultrasonic deterrent sound fields, which could be utilized to improve effectiveness of the deterrent. The DOE research culminated in a 2017 final report highlighting the results of the updated design and deployment modifications tests to the turbine-mounted deterrent system at the California Ridge Wind Energy facility. For more information, see Ultrasonic Bat Deterrent Technology Final Technical Report.

Project_Title: Evaluating the Effectiveness of an Ultrasonic Acoustic Deterrent (UAD) in Reducing Bat Fatalities at Wind Energy Facilities
FOA_Name: Bat Impact Minimization Technologies and Field Testing Opportunities FOA
Project_Description:
Bat Conservation International (BCI) recently completed research to advance the design of a pezio-electronic ultrasonic acoustic bat deterrent device, and carried out a full-scale validation of its effectiveness at a wind plant.  The listing of several bat species as threatened or endangered presents siting and permitting challenges for new facilities and mitigation challenges for existing wind energy facilities. Currently, the only scientifically proven strategy to consistently reduce bat fatalities at wind turbines is operational minimization. Recently published studies indicate that feathering the blades below a higher-than-normal cut-in speed (e.g., 1.5–3.0 m/s above the manufacturer’s cut-in speed) results in an average 50% reduction in bat fatalities compared to normally operating turbines. However, altering turbine operations, even on a limited-term basis, may pose operational and financial challenges for wind energy operators, particularly in low wind regions. Moreover, operational minimization may not be effective for all species (e.g., bats capable of flying at higher wind speeds). Thus, there is a need to develop alternative solutions that reduce bat fatalities while allowing turbines to operate normally.
The purpose of this project is to assess the effectiveness of an ultrasonic acoustic deterrent (UAD) to reduce bat activity and fatality at wind turbines. The major project objectives are to 1) determine the best placement and orientation of the UAD to ensure safety, compatibility and functionality of the devices, 2) assess the functionality of a newly redesigned UAD, 3) investigate the effectiveness of the technology in reducing bat fatality at wind turbines based on UAD placement and orientation, 4) directly compare the costs and benefits of UADs to operational minimization (i.e., feathering blades and raising cut-in speeds of wind turbines to reduce bat fatality), and 5) examine whether a synergistic interaction exists between operational minimization and deterrents.

Project_Title: Evaluating the Effectiveness of a Camera-Based Detection System to Support Informed Curtailment and Minimize Eagle Fatalities at Wind Energy Facilities
FOA_Name: Wind Energy – Eagle Impact Minimization Technologies and Field Testing Opportunities
Project_Description:
This project will evaluate of the effectiveness of a technology intended to help reduce eagle collisions with wind turbines. IdentiFlight, developed by RES in collaboration with Boulder Imaging, is an autonomous aerial monitoring and detection system. High-precision optical technology installed atop an IdentiFlight tower detects, identifies, and tracks eagles flying within a one-kilometer hemisphere around the IdentiFlight tower. IdentiFlight is intended to facilitate turbine shutdown (also known as ‘informed curtailment’) to reduce collision risk of golden eagles and other protected species. IdentiFlight uses two camera types and a classification algorithm based on machine vision learning. Once an object is detected, IdentiFlight directs a camera to point at the object to determine distance to the object and to gather data to determine if the object is an eagle or not. Video footage is reviewed by technicians and avian experts who then update IdentiFlight’s image library, and this library is used to improve IdentiFlight’s classification algorithms. The position of any bird being tracked is transmitted to a central user interface along with the classification confidence statistic. At the user interface, the bird proximity to a turbine, velocity vector, classification result, and more will be used to activate specific curtailment strategies through signals to turbine operators or automated curtailment of turbines through Supervisory Control and Data Acquisition (SCADA).
The American Wind Wildlife Institute (AWWI) is conducting an independent, 3rd-party evaluation of IdentiFlight’s ability to detect large birds, correctly classify them as eagles or non-eagles, and make curtailment decisions at wind facilities. The results of this multi-year, multi-site evaluation of IdentiFlight’s performance will provide a credible estimate of the reduction in collision risk to eagles gained through the implementation of IdentiFlight. This study will be used by the wind industry and regulatory agencies to inform the appropriate application of IdentiFlight in Eagle Conservation Plans and other conservation measures to reduce collision risk of target species.

Project_Title: Detection and Perception of Sound by Eagles and Surrogate Raptors
FOA_Name: Wind Energy – Eagle Impact Minimization Technologies and Field Testing Opportunities
Project_Description: Sound-based deterrent systems are a viable pathway for reducing eagle mortality, yet we have very little information on the hearing capabilities of bald and golden eagles, making the design of an effective auditory deterrent extremely difficult. This project conducted an 18-month research program with three distinct activities: 1) map the auditory abilities of bald and golden eagles; 2) record and analyze the vocalizations of bald eagles to inform development of acoustic deterrents; and 3) in a controlled lab setting, evaluate the response of bald eagles to several acoustic stimuli. The study also conducted hearing assessments on red-tailed hawks as a potential surrogate species for future technology validation. The project was designed to provide information in a form that is relevant and easily transferrable to technology development communities, specifically those involved in developing detection and deterrence technologies for eagles and other avian species.

Project_Title: Understanding the Golden Eagle sensory world to enhance detection and response to wind turbines
FOA_Name: Wind Energy – Eagle Impact Minimization Technologies and Field Testing Opportunities
Project_Description: The goals of this project are to: (1) measure key components of the visual and auditory systems of golden eagles (Aquila chrysaetos) and bald eagles (Haliaeetus leucocephalus), (2) run simple behavioral tests in wildlife rehabilitation centers to determine the responses of eagles (attraction, avoidance, neutral) to combinations of conspicuous visual and acoustic stimuli, and (3) provide recommendations (based on sensory physiology) to engineers for development of deterrent or alerting signals that can be implemented in the field. These signals tuned specifically to the golden and bald eagle sensory worlds could then be used for field tests at wind farms, leading to much more efficient eagle, and potentially other raptor, deterrent technologies.

Project_Title: Evaluating the Effectiveness of a Detection and Deterrent System in Reducing Eagle Fatalities at Operational Wind Facilities
FOA_Name: Wind Energy – Eagle Impact Minimization Technologies and Field Testing Opportunities
Project_Description:
The DTBird system evaluated in this study includes a video-surveillance detection module and a deterrence module. DTBird’s detection system scans its surroundings for large birds but is not designed to classify targets or distinguish between species. In this study, the deterrent system is optimized for targets equivalent in size to an eagle with approximately 2-meter wing span. If the automated detection module locks on to a target and perceives that the target has entered a determined collision risk zone, the deterrence module first emits an audible warning signal. If the surveillance system perceives that the target crosses a second, closer distance threshold, then the deterrence module emits a stronger dissuasion signal intended to encourage the bird to change its flight path and avoid the turbine. Technical specifications for this project are based on the model DTBirdV4D8, with four HD wide-angle cameras located every 90° on the tower of the wind turbine 5-10 meters above the ground, and eight speakers, four located by the cameras and four at 90° on the tower of the wind turbine ~10-20 meters below the nacelle. 
American Wind Wildlife Institute (AWWI) is conducting an independent, 3rd-party evaluation of DTBird’s ability to detect large birds in a suite of environmental conditions using Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs, also known as drones) shaped and painted to look like a golden eagle. The Project Team will review DTBird video recordings of the technology’s observations of wild eagles and other raptors to evaluate these species behavioral response in reaction to exposure to DTBird’s warning and dissuasion signals. The Project Team will also conduct a two-year controlled experiment to evaluate the flight behavior of eagles near turbines with DTBird units that have deterrent signals activated (experimental treatment) and muted (control). The results of this multi-year, multi-site evaluation of DTBird’s performance will provide a credible estimate of the reduction in collision risk to eagles gained through the implementation of DTBird. This study will be used by the wind industry and regulatory agencies to inform the appropriate implementation of DTBird in Eagle Conservation Plans and other conservation measures. The study will also provide new insights to eagle and raptor behavior in and near to wind energy facilities, further informing development of such plans.
The project objectives of this study are to 1) evaluate the multi-site effectiveness of DTBird in minimizing the risk of colliding with wind turbines for golden eagles and suitable surrogate raptors (e.g., bald eagles and red-tailed hawks); and 2) quantify the expected reduction in collision risk from deploying DTBird in a manner that helps the U.S. Fish & Wildlife Service assess and credit facility operators for their efforts to reduce fatalities, and update estimates of eagle take for use in incidental take permits. The Project Team will also provide information to help refine and improve the technology to maximize its effectiveness and practical application. Data will be collected at two geographically distinct wind energy facilities over two years at each facility.

Project_Title: Eagle Take Minimization System
FOA_Name: Wind Energy – Eagle Impact Minimization Technologies and Field Testing Opportunities
Project_Description: Laufer Wind has developed a prototype Eagle Take Minimization System with the potential for autonomously detecting, tracking, and visually identifying eagles and other protected birds out to approximately 1 km range with no human verification required. This type of detection system is an important component of eagle impact minimization solutions at wind farms. Early detection and positive identification of species of concern can facilitate early shut-down of high-risk turbines, or trigger deterrents to reduce or avoid eagle collisions with operational wind turbines. The objective of this project was to develop a networked system comprised of a sensor-fused commercial-off-the-shelf X-band radar (to detect far-field objects), a Pan-Tilt-Zoom visible-spectrum camera (to identify the object), and a central controller computer to process the radar and visual data and interface with a wind facility Supervisory Control and Data Acquisition (SCADA) to inform turbine curtailment, or to trigger a deterrent if an eagle is within a high-risk proximity to an operating wind turbine. For more information see the Eagle Take Minimization System Final Report.

Project_Title: A Heterogeneous System for Eagle Detection, Deterrent, and Wildlife Collision Detection for Wind Turbines
FOA_Name: Wind Energy – Eagle Impact Minimization Technologies and Field Testing Opportunities
Project_Description:
To minimize the impact of wind energy on wildlife, Oregon State University (OSU) is developing a system of intelligent sensors that can automatically detect and identify eagles using machine vision, remotely activate one or more ground-based kinetic visual deterrents, and automatically detect and photograph any objects colliding with a wind turbine blade. Three fundamental objectives are proposed for the project:
  • Detection of eagles flying in proximity of wind turbines including flight trajectory prediction
  • Eagle deterrence using inflatable ground visual deterrents
  • Automatic blade collision detection for continuous monitoring

Project_Title: Wind Turbine Dynamometer Upgrade
FOA_Name: American Recovery and Reinvestment Act
Project_Description: The National Renewable Energy Laboratory designed, fabricated, constructed, installed, and commissioned a 5-megawatt dynamometer at the laboratory's National Wind Technology Center (NWTC). This new facility more than doubled the NWTC's capacity (rated power) for testing wind turbine drivetrains and has sufficient capacity to test the largest wind turbine drivetrains envisioned for land-based markets. The dynamometer allows for more complete simulation of wind turbine operating conditions than had been previously available.

Project_Title: Development of a Concentrated Winding Permanent Magnet Alternator for a Small Wind Turbine
Program_Area: Distributed Wind; Next-Generation Technology Development and Manufacturing
FOA_Name: Small Business Innovation Research Phase I, Release 2
Project_Description: This project will develop an advanced high-performance alternator for an American-made small wind turbine for residential, farm and small business applications. The new alternator design will apply advanced concepts developed for hybrid electric vehicles.

Project_Title: SMART Wind Health: Development of an Inexpensive Prognostic Condition Monitoring/Control System for Distributed Wind Turbines
FOA_Name: Small Technology Transfer Phase I, Release 2
Project_Description: Wind turbine maintenance, particularly in remote locations, is a substantial cost, and industry leaders have identified inexpensive fault monitoring as a top priority to increase competitiveness. This research will utilize low-cost readily available sensors and processors to develop a commercial “SMART Wind Health Watch and Control System” addressing this need.

Project_Title: Abrasion/Impact Resistant Coatings for Wind Turbine Blade Protection
FOA_Name: Small Business Innovation Research Phase I and II, Release 2
Project_Description: This project will develop a tough and durable coating to address the erosion of wind turbine blades that can be caused by winds, rain, ice and sand. The proposed solution promises to fill a key technological gap and address a critical need in the wind turbine industry.

Project_Title: Thermodynamic Profiler for the Marine Atmospheric Boundary Layer Observations
Program_Area: Offshore Wind; Atmosphere to electrons: Plant Optimization and Resource Characterization
FOA_Name: Small Business Innovation Research Release 2, Phase I and II
Project_Description: The service life of offshore wind turbines is about 20 years and during their lifetime they must operate and survive a wide range of atmospheric conditions (hurricane winds, icing conditions, and other weather extremes). In addition, their performance during operational life should be optimal with respect to power production, minimization of mechanical stresses, plant wake distribution, and more. Microwave radiometers provide accurate assessments of atmospheric stability in the atmospheric boundary layer, affecting both the loads and power production of wind turbines. The proposed buoy-based Marine Profiling Radiometer will deliver thermodynamic profile data including temperature, humidity profiles, and integrated liquid and water vapor paths throughout the atmosphere. These data provide essential information about the marine atmospheric boundary layer status and are inputs for numerical weather simulation model initialization. The availability of this information improves long-term and short-term localized weather forecasts, provides information about atmospheric stability, can provide advance warning about thunderstorms, icing conditions, cloud liquid and ice content and rain rate measurements, and more.

Project_Title: Advancing Technology for Offshore Wind Resource Characterizations
Program_Area: Offshore Wind; Atmosphere to electrons: Plant Optimization and Resource Characterization
FOA_Name: Small Business Innovation Research Release 2, Phase I and II
Project_Description: There is a need for technology innovation in development of a low-cost marine atmospheric boundary layer (MABL) measurement system which could serve as a core element of a buoy-based data collection network for the offshore renewable energy industry. The objective is to complete development, testing, and validation of a low cost, low power marine atmospheric boundary layer radar measurement system which can serve as a core element of a buoy-based data collection network for the offshore renewable energy industry. The heart of the proposed atmospheric measurement system is a compact wind profiling radar instrument that provides buoy-based atmospheric  characterization for offshore wind applications. The radar will collect profiles of wind speed and direction to heights of over 300m and provide communication rates appropriate for advanced rapid refresh weather modeling. The atmospheric measurement package size, weight, and power consumption are suitable for deployment on existing met-ocean buoy platforms.

Project_Title: Innovative Deepwater Mooring for Floating Offshore Wind
FOA_Name: Small Business Innovation Research Phase I and II, Release 2
Project_Description: The cost of anchoring offshore floating wind turbines is an obstacle to reducing the cost of energy from offshore floating wind projects and presents an opportunity for savings. Triton will address the opportunity with an innovative deep water anchoring system that will lower capital expenditure costs for wind farm development.

Project_Title: Weathervane Optimizer
Program_Area: Next-Generation Technology Development and Manufacturing; Atmosphere to electrons: Plant Optimization and Resource Characterization
FOA_Name: Small Business Innovation Research Phase I, Release 2
Project_Description:
The goal Michigan Aerospace Corporation’s Weathervane Optimizer Phase 2 program was to develop software and hardware for modern Wind Turbine Generators (WTGs) that allow for the prediction of turbine component failures and the prevention of catastrophic turbine damage during extreme wind events. The long-term objective of this work was to introduce advanced control strategies and Lidar sensors that will ultimately reduce the cost of energy (CoE) in the wind market by improving WTG lifetime and efficiency. During Phase 2, major technical achievements has been accomplished on three fronts:
  • Progress toward a viable ultraviolet (UV) Lidar (light detection and ranging) sensor for the advanced measurement of the wind flow field incident on the turbines.
  • The development of flexible, powerful Condition Monitoring (CM) algorithms and predictive analytics, based primarily on Bayesian networks and influence diagrams.
  • The development of control strategies that combine the power of CM with feed-forward Lidar measurements to improve the lifetime and efficiency of WTGs.

Project_Title: Distributed Low Power On-Blade Control for Wind Turbine Load Mitigation
FOA_Name: Small Business Innovation Research Phase I, Release 2
Project_Description:
The economic viability of wind energy is critically dependent upon robust, long duration operation, while minimizing outages and costs for repair and ongoing maintenance. Active load mitigation offers a way to control both peak and fatigue inducing loads so as to forestall major failures, preclude costly repairs and service interruptions, and extend the life of wind turbine blades, generator components and the entire turbine system. Mitigation of loads requires some form of adaptation of the turbine to variable conditions (e.g., atmospheric turbulence, wind speed variation, turbine to turbine interaction, tower shadow), and these needs can be addressed through an application of “smart” materials-based devices to provide on blade aerodynamic control. 
A novel actuation system, previously developed for on-blade helicopter rotor control applications, is proposed for use on wind turbines as a means of actively mitigating excessive wind turbine loads. The device uses shape memory alloy (SMA) materials as its prime mover; is compact, low power, and robust; and can be designed as an integral member of a rotor blade or as a separate retrofit device to enhance existing wind turbine installations. Applications include active load control of extended length wind turbine blades, low-speed performance improvement on existing and new blade systems, and improved blade endurance and fatigue life through reduction of vibratory loads from atmospheric and upwind wind turbine turbulence. 
Phase I of the research program is to understand and address the scaling issues associated with transitioning this technology from helicopter aerospace applications to wind turbine blade design and operational use. Phase II is to execute a design/build/test program to validate the actuation concept’s effectiveness at load reduction, and suggest improvements and modifications necessary to implement these actuators on both future turbine rotors and as a retrofit improvement onto existing rotors on installed turbines.

Project_Title: Full-scale Wake Steering Demonstration (TCF)
Program_Area: Atmosphere to electrons: Plant Optimization and Resource Characterization
FOA_Name: Technology Commercialization Fund
Project_Description:
Over the last few decades, wind energy has evolved into a large international industry involving major players in the manufacturing, construction, and utility sectors. Coinciding with the industry’s growth, significant technology innovation has resulted in larger turbines with lower associated costs of energy and more complex designs in all subsystems. However, as the deployment of the technology grows, and its role within the electricity sector becomes more prominent, so have the expectations of the technology in terms of performance, reliability, and cost. The industry currently partitions its efforts into separate paths for turbine design, plant design and development, finance, grid interaction and operation, mitigation of adverse community and environmental impacts, and other areas. 
The Rotor Wake Measurements and Predictions for Validation project is the experimental validation hub of the DOE Atmosphere to Electrons (A2e) program. Researchers working on this project have provided high-fidelity observations and model validation support for the Advanced Flow Control Science for Wind Plants, High-Fidelity Modeling and Integrated Systems Design and Analysis projects. In this project, researchers have applied a validation and uncertainty quantification framework to perform validation studies using data gathered from existing public data sets. They have also gathered new data sets and performed model validation studies using observations from the Sandia Scaled Wind Farm Technology (SWiFT) facility, NREL’s National Wind Technology Center and the NextEra Energy Peetz Table wind farm. The data includes observations of the atmosphere and turbine interactions within wind plants under both standard operating conditions, as well as those useful for wind farm control. The project includes further development and design of testing facilities at the SWiFT site including the National Rotor Testbed (NRT) rotor. Plans for future testing in full scale wind plants have been made and initial utility scale testing has commenced at the Peetz Table wind farm.

Project_Title: Lidar Buoy Science
Program_Area: Offshore Wind; Atmosphere to electrons: Plant Optimization and Resource Characterization
Project_Description:
Pacific Northwest National Laboratory (PNNL) operates two LIDAR buoys for DOE. The centerpiece of the instrumentation for each buoy is a motion-corrected LIDAR system that can provide profiles of the wind speed and direction from the surface to 200 m. In addition to a LIDAR, each buoy collects ocean temperature, salinity, current, and wave data as well as near-surface air temperature, humidity, and wind speed and direction. Prior to deployment of DOE’s lidar buoys, there had been limited or no wind and wave resource data in the BOEM designated Wind Energy Areas to allow confident deployment and operation of wind turbines in the offshore environment. Resource assessment data are critical to determining the expected annual energy output from a wind plant as well as proper turbine and plant design. Further, meteorological and oceanographic (metocean) data that are privately obtained for project siting purposes are generally proprietary, which limits further research opportunities and benefits to the wind industry. This project has three primary objectives:
  • Deploy DOE’s lidar buoys either directly in support of DOE projects or through loan or partnership agreements to support the development of offshore wind energy in the United States
  • Analyze data collected by the buoys to validate resource characterization offshore and to gain additional insight into how air-sea interaction physics affect the wind profile
  • Make the data collected and associated analyses publicly available for the benefit of offshore wind energy development in the United States.
For more information, see Lidar Buoy Data Analysis: Basic Assessment of Observed Conditions and Instrument Performance Off Virginia and New Jersey Report.

Project_Title: Optimized Carbon Fiber Composites for Wind Turbine Blades
Project_Description: The main purpose of this project is to assess the commercial viability to develop cost-competitive wind-specific carbon fiber composites to enable larger rotors for increased energy capture. This will be achieved through material test article fabrication, mechanical testing, and blade manufacturing cost model development and analysis. The impact of this work will be to both lower LCOE which directly impacts national objectives on climate and oil dependency, as well as increase U.S. manufacturing competitiveness. Improved and unique materials could provide domestic manufacturers a competitive advantage, leading to more U.S. jobs to supply the domestic and export markets. The results of this project will be broadly applicable to the wind industry, ranging from OEM’s and blade manufacturers to material suppliers. Additionally, this work will have benefits to other industries especially transportation, where lower cost carbon fiber composites could be more broadly applied.

Project_Title: Technology Development and Innovation to Address Operational Challenges
Project_Description: National Renewable Energy Laboratory (NREL) will collaborate with technology developers over a three-year period (FY17–FY19) to support the characterization, development, and engineering of emerging technologies that detect and deter birds and bats at wind energy facilities. The project will utilize the DOE’s National Wind Technology Center (NWTC) facilities and expertise at NREL to support the research and development of these technologies. Technologies to be evaluated may consist of stand-alone systems as well as integrated, multi-component systems. Integration with turbine systems, such as SCADA systems or installation considerations, will also be examined. Technologies at various technology readiness levels (TRLs) will be considered for this effort with a focus on TRLs 3 through 5. The engineering evaluations conducted by NREL will support biological field studies being conducted by other organizations, such as the American Wind Wildlife Institute as part of its Technology Verification program. A longer term objective may include the support or development of an engineering standard or certification process for these technologies, which may be done by NREL or by a third party.

Project_Title: Atmosphere to Electrons (A2e) Performance Risk, Uncertainty and Finance (PRUF) Analysis Support
Program_Area: Atmosphere to electrons: Plant Optimization and Resource Characterization; Next-Generation Technology Development and Manufacturing
Project_Description: The Performance Risk, Uncertainty and Finance (PRUF) focus area will contribute to the DOE wind program objectives by improving the understanding of the risk and uncertainty factors associated with long term operation of wind power plants. Improving the predictability and reliability of wind power generation and operations will increase certainty for investors and bring new capital into the wind energy space. PRUF will investigate the impact that project uncertainties have on financial structures, the cost of capital, the cost of ownership and operations, and the levelized cost of energy (LCOE) for wind. In FY17, Argonne National Laboratory (ANL) will start supporting the PRUF project, building on its recent experience in modeling/analysis of electricity markets with high shares of renewable energy and statistical algorithms for improved wind power forecasting. Initially, ANL will provide review, inputs, and suggestion in terms of project priorities, methodological approaches, and deliverables. ANL will also initiate work on quantitative analysis of wind power uncertainties and corresponding risk assessment for wind power investors. More specifically, ANL will assist in identifying and quantifying relevant risks for investors in wind power projects throughout the lifetime of a wind power plant, i.e. through review of literature and interaction with the industry partners in the project. In particular, in FY17 ANL will focus on how electricity market design, power system operational procedures, and short-term forecasting uncertainty may influence deviation penalties, potential curtailments, operational profits, and the overall investment risk for a wind power project. The goal is to assess the magnitude of these operational risks compared to other risk factors facing wind power investors. ANL will also start developing ideas for an analytical framework based on statistical methods for quantifying the full range of relevant uncertainties and how they may influence project risk. The latter activity will be coordinated with related work that is already underway at National Renewable Energy Laboratory (NREL) and will, eventually, support the wind resource assessment benchmark project within PRUF.

Project_Title: Atmosphere to Electrons (A2e) Performance Risk, Uncertainty and Finance (PRUF) Analysis Support
Program_Area: Atmosphere to electrons: Plant Optimization and Resource Characterization; Next-Generation Technology Development and Manufacturing
Project_Description:
Performance risk and uncertainty surrounding energy (and hence revenue) generation can negatively impact wind project finance, and by extension wind’s levelized cost of electricity (LCOE), in three primary ways: by inflating the cost of debt, by inflating the cost of equity, and by reducing the debt/equity ratio. It follows that wind’s LCOE can, therefore, be lowered simply by reducing performance risk and uncertainty in ways that flow through to improvements in these three financing terms. But what is the size of the overall opportunity to reduce wind’s LCOE solely through performance risk reduction? Where do the most effective opportunities for targeted risk reduction lie? Do the answers change when focusing on different market and policy environments?  Knowing the size of the overall opportunity, as well as the relative effectiveness of targeted opportunities, will help to justify, motivate, inform, and support the broader A2e R&D portfolio. 
This project will focus on the aforementioned movements in the various interest rate components, as well as financial modeling to analyze the potential impact on LCOE (both with and without the PTC) as interest rates finally begin to rise from their multi-year lows (recognizing that wind power tends to be more capital-intensive—and therefore more sensitive to finance—than conventional generation). Work on this task will commence following completion of the bookending analysis. In executing both of these tasks, LBNL will interact with and coordinate with National Renewable Energy Laboratory (NREL) and the broader A2e/PRUF team, as well as several financial industry practitioners, to ensure smooth and efficient execution of the work, as well as broad uptake of the results among the larger A2e community.

Project_Title: Offshore Wind Strategy Follow on Analysis
Program_Area: Next-Generation Technology Development and Manufacturing; Offshore Wind
Project_Description:
Offshore wind is a unique resource and an area of focus for the DOE wind program based on its relative abundance, the presence of high-quality resources in many coastal areas, proximity and correlation to load, and its need for pre-commercial Technology Readiness Level 2-4 research and development (R&D) to enable increased cost effectiveness. This project focuses on techno-economic analysis activities to inform the DOE offshore wind research agenda by characterizing and analyzing key trends in offshore wind markets and technology and assessing the impact of potential future offshore wind R&D areas of focus. The project also seeks to quantify the value proposition of offshore wind technologies to the power system. Analysis activities are summarized in three project tasks:
  • Offshore Wind System Benefits Analysis: Understand and quantify the value of offshore wind to the electricity system, ratepayers, and industry through grid modeling.
  • Floating Offshore Wind Innovation Pathways: Analyze potential innovations in floating offshore wind system design, installation, operations, and maintenance for their impact on costs. This work is conducted in concert with the Integrated Planning and Portfolio Analysis project on a systems-level, multi-fidelity, lifetime cost framework and intended to evaluate archetype floating substructure concepts.
  • Market, Risk, and Resource Analysis: Collect and characterize key market and cost data for use by decision makers in the public and private sectors and the DOE wind program. This work maintains an empirical baseline of the technology to inform research and development decisions. Findings from this analysis are also be used to inform the annual NREL Cost of Energy Review and related DOE wind program annual reporting requirements to the Office of Management and Budget.
For more information, see Offshore Wind Energy Resource Assessment for Alaska report and The Vineyard Wind Power Purchase Agreement: Insights for Estimating Costs of U.S. Offshore Wind Projects report.

Project_Title: Atmosphere to Electrons (A2e) Performance Risk, Uncertainty and Finance (PRUF) Analysis Support
Program_Area: Atmosphere to electrons: Plant Optimization and Resource Characterization
Project_Description:
The goal of PRUF is to understand and mitigate the associated risks with developing, owning, and operating wind power plants. This requires mapping project finance related uncertainty to identify the major pre-construction risks for investors. PRUF encompasses a wide range of risk reduction activities including performance benchmarking, quantification of performance variability, and operations research. The scope of PRUF includes providing support to related industry working groups, such as the Power Curve Working Group and the Consortium for Advancement of Remote Sensing to help identify the best pathways to reduce uncertainty associated with power curves and resource measurements. The primary focus area of PRUF is the Wind Plant Performance Prediction (WP3) Benchmarking activity, which is a first of its kind data sharing and analysis initiative between major wind industry stakeholders. The WP3 task can have a significant positive near term impact on wind deployment and LCOE—lessons learned through WP3 can rapidly find their way into industry standards and practices, given the close working relationship between project stakeholders. WP3 aggregates energy yield predictions from consultants and provides critical feedback on the accuracy and uncertainty of those predictions. This facilitates greater investor confidence in the predicted outcomes, and therefore reduces risk premiums associated with wind project investment. Because the PRUF team works closely with industry leading consultants to identify modeling deficiencies, WP3 is able to accelerate the adoption of new methods for estimating energy production. There are three project objectives for the benchmark effort that will accomplish the above outcomes:
  • Generate accurate, independent benchmarks of current pre-construction energy assessment accuracy;
  • Improve accuracy and reduce uncertainty in pre-construction energy estimates; and,
  • Create an open knowledge sharing platform that provides state-of-the-art methods and models for pre-construction and operational energy assessments.
Ultimately, WP3 benefits project owners, consultancies, OEMs, and project investors by reducing project risk and enabling greater investment and deployment across the industry.

Project_Title: Working Together to Resolve Environmental Effects of Wind Energy (WREN)
Project_Description: Wind impacts on wildlife affect both wind farm power production and generate regulatory and legal uncertainty for projects. The project supports research and development of technical solutions that address these challenges and provide broad access to the current understanding of the science. WREN (Working Together to Resolve Environmental Effects of Wind Energy), also known as the International Energy Agency’s (IEA’s) Wind Task 34, facilitates international collaboration to advance the global understanding of environmental effects of offshore and land-based wind energy development, through continued U.S. participation. Tethysis an online resource for wind-wildlife impacts research that facilitates the exchange of information and data on the environmental effects of land-based and offshore wind. Tethys is also a repository for information generated through WREN, and acts as a platform for engagement with the international wind community. The Tethys database also includes a Map Viewer, which provides visitors a visual understanding of where relevant research is taking place across the United States. The Avian Remote Sensing task continues development of the ThermalTrackertechnology, which began in 2011. During the peer review period, PNNL advanced the technology to integrate real-time detection processing, stereo vision for 3D avian flight track analysis, and species identification to enable long-term continuous monitoring of avian activity around wind sites for baseline studies and to meet regulatory requirements during operation. ThermalTracker supports continuous observation of species-specific avian activity around wind turbines to provide the species-specific data needed to adequately evaluate risk and reduce scientific uncertainty, especially for offshore locations that are difficult to study using existing methods.

Project_Title: Working Together to Resolve Environmental Effects of Wind Energy (WREN)
Project_Description: Impacts of wind energy development on wildlife have been a concern for decades and the challenges vary by species (e.g., bats vs. eagles), habitat (e.g., forest vs. cropland, or land-based vs. offshore), and regulatory environment (e.g., variation in cost of monitoring and compliance among jurisdictions). The implications can result in potential delays or abandonment of projects, or alterations to normal operations resulting in reduced renewable energy generation. To address these challenges, the National Renewable Energy Laboratory (NREL) engages a range of stakeholders through a href="https://www.nationalwind.org/" target="_blank"> the National Wind Coordinating Collaborative and Bats and Wind Energy Cooperativeto collaborate on identifying high-priority issues and conducting science-based research. Outreach and engagement, both nationally and internationally, are also important to expand access to information and exchange expertise for the benefit of all parties. The purpose of this project is to facilitate more efficient and cost-effective wind energy deployment across the United States through focused research and development (R&D) and the dissemination of high-quality information. The primary efforts involve characterizing the effectiveness of wildlife impact minimization strategies, which will lead to reliable and lower-cost solutions than current impact minimization practices, such as curtailing turbine operations based solely on wind speed. This project involves partnering with technology innovators as part of the Technology Development and Innovation (TD&I) program.TD&I is an effort to support the advancement of experimental, early- to mid-level technologies aimed at reducing bird and bat fatalities, one of the key barriers to wind development. NREL is also focusing on the restructuring of collaborative, multi-stakeholder research and development (R&D) efforts to develop or improve methodologies for better understanding of impacts from wind energy to prairie grouse .This effort uses the Department of Energy’s (DOE’s) National Wind Technology Center (NWTC) and expertise at NREL to support the development, evaluation, and advancement of technologies between Technology Readiness Levels (TRLs) 3 and 5, preparing these technologies for large-scale testing at operational wind farms. In addition, NREL oversees research-focused collaboratives, including the Land-Based Collaborative (LBC) and the International Energy Agency Technology Collaboration Program on Wind (IEA Wind) Task 34 (or WREN – Working Together to Resolve Environmental Effects of Wind Energy). The LBC and WREN perform activities are critical to the development of monitoring and minimization strategies. Information dissemination is essential in catalyzing technology development and increasing the knowledge base for all stakeholders. NREL leverages the outreach and engagement resources of WREN, in partnership with the Pacific Northwest National Laboratory (PNNL) and LBC partners (i.e., American Wind Wildlife Institute (AWWI), facilitators of the National Wind Coordinating Collaborative (NWCC); and Bat Conservation International (BCI), facilitators of the Bats and Wind Energy Cooperative (BWEC)) to synthesize and share data with key stakeholders. Information on research and related information from both land-based and offshore wind can be found at WREN. The overarching objectives of these activities are the reduction of 1) the levelized cost of energy (LCOE) of wind energy, and 2) barriers to expanded wind energy development through the leveraging of national and global R&D and information pertaining to wind energy-wildlife interactions. Through this project, NREL has also contributed to the development of various reports and guidance frameworks such as the Framework for testing Bat and Eagle Impact-Reduction Strategies and the Comprehensive Guide to Studying Wind Energy/Wildlife Interactions.

Project_Title: Atmosphere to Electrons (A2e): Mesoscale Physics and Inflow: Wind Forecast Improvement Project (WFIP 2) Wind Profilers Support
Program_Area: Atmosphere to electrons: Plant Optimization and Resource Characterization
Project_Description: The development of wind energy in the United States, both terrestrial and offshore, is hampered in several ways by a lack of atmospheric observations. For terrestrial wind, resource characterization including forecasting is constrained by errors in mesoscale and large eddy simulation scale models that arise in part from initialization errors. In 2015, Pacific Northwest National Laboratory (PNNL) installed three 449 MHz wind profiling radars on the Washington and Oregon coasts with the support of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA). The data provided by these measurement systems are a valuable source of forecast model initialization with the expectation of improving day-ahead forecasts as far east as the central United States. The West Coast locations are especially useful for this, since storms track eastward from the West Coast of the United States. The data provided valuable information to the second Wind Forecast Improvement Project (WFIP 2), the study area for which was immediately downwind of the profilers in the northwestern United States. WFIP 2 helped improve the representation of physical processes in resource characterization models. The project resulted in forecast improvements that will significantly reduce barriers to the development of terrestrial wind energy in the United States.

Project_Title: Sensor Array for Remote Monitoring (Oregon State University Support)
Program_Area: Environmental Impacts and Siting; Offshore Wind
Project_Description: Bird and bat interactions with offshore wind turbines are not well understood. However, various stakeholders, including permitting agencies and nongovernmental organizations (NGOs) have raised concerns. Although carcass searches can be conducted at land-based wind facilities as part of a monitoring protocol to determine impacts, offshore projects do not lend themselves to searching and collecting carcasses. Therefore, impacts at the turbine, project, or population level are not discernible. As an awardee under the DOE U.S. Offshore Wind: Removing Market Barriers Funding Opportunity, Oregon State University (OSU) was selected to develop an integrated sensor array that would be able to continuously monitor interactions (including impacts) of birds and bats on the nacelle, tower, and blades of a wind turbine, and facilitate data transfer back to shore for post processing. OSU has completed the funded effort and is working towards identifying interest and support to further develop the system to a point where it can be commercialized.

Project_Title: Offshore Floating Vertical-Axis Wind Turbine
Project_Description:
Sandia is performing an offshore vertical axis wind turbine (VAWT) feasibility study. The motivation for this work is that floating VAWTs are a potential transformative technology solution to reduce offshore wind LCOE (levelized cost of energy) in deep-water. The project will investigate the technical and economic feasibility of a deep-water floating VAWT system; and is structured into three primary work packages:
  • Platform and Mooring Design & Cost Studies
  • Upscaling Analysis
  • LCOE Analysis
The potential benefit of a floating VAWT is envisioned through system-level improvements and BoS (balance of station) cost reductions, which are addressed in the project through platform and mooring design studies that feed into LCOE analysis.

Project_Title: Eagle Topic Area 3 Funding Opportunity Announcement (FOA) Support
Project_Description: The Eagle Impact Minimization Technologies and Field Testing Opportunities funding opportunity announcement (FOA) seeks to address the following objectives through three Topic Areas that seek to 1) expand the scientific basis of and number of technical options available, 2) stimulate development of novel impact minimization technologies, and 3) test and verify near-commercial systems. In support of this effort, NREL will coordinate and provide technical support to the FOA Topic Area 3 awardees to ensure standardization of research and data collection plans, as well as coordinating a comparative meta-analysis, as appropriate, of findings across all relevant awardees to assess the comparative efficiency of each impact minimization technology.

Project_Title: Novel Medium Speed Wind Turbine Generator
FOA_Name: Small Business Innovation Research Phase I, Release 2
Project_Description: LC Drives will develop a medium-speed generator for utility-scale wind that is less than half the size of current technology available in the market today. This advanced wind generator concept leverages patented and ongoing development efforts that LC Drives has developed for marine propulsion applications. This technological breakthrough cools the motor windings more effectively thereby allowing both higher slot current density and increased torque in a given volume, resulting in a dramatic reduction in the size and weight of the generator. LC Drives estimates that the beneficial system wide effects of a smaller, lighter weight generator have the potential to reduce the Levelized Cost of Energy (LCOE) for a 3MW or larger class wind turbine by up to 3 percent.

Project_Title: Development of a Turbine Blade Surface Coating to Reduce the Threat of Lightning
FOA_Name: Small Business Innovation Research Release 2, Phase I and II
Project_Description: Every year, the global wind industry loses an estimated $100M or more to damage caused by lightning. A new blade coating will reduce the damage to wind turbine blades caused by lightning by promoting the formation of ionization channels over the surface of the turbine blades, providing a safe external path for lightning energy to reach ground and preventing damaging blade punctures. The coating consists of discrete conductive elements embedded in a non-conducting substrate and mixed with a topcoat, which will be applied to the blade surface near the tips to enhance the performance of the lightning protection system. Improved wind turbine lightning protection systems will reduce the cost of wind energy by reducing O&M expenses and minimizing turbine downtime, project risk, and costly insurance claims. These steps will increase wind energy’s competitiveness with traditional fuel sources nationwide (even without federal subsidies), widen adoption nationwide, and increase the nation’s energy security and stability.

Project_Title: A Concrete Additive Manufacturing Process for Fixed and Floating Wind Turbine Foundations and Towers
Program_Area: Next-Generation Technology Development and Manufacturing; Offshore Wind
FOA_Name: Small Technology Transfer Phase I, Release 2
Project_Description: This project will develop and assess the feasibility of an innovative concrete additive manufacturing process for building a variety of offshore and land-based wind turbine tower and foundation configurations on-site. The advanced manufacturing method reduces the capital cost of an offshore substructure and tower compared to conventional methods by up to 80% using low-cost regionally sourced concrete without expensive formwork, and increases production speed up to 20 times using an automated production-line approach. The initial target application of the additive manufacturing process is a 160-m tall gravity-based foundation and concrete tower for an offshore 10-MW turbine installed in 40-m of water.

Project_Title: Unsteady Surface Pressure Measurement System Suitable for Making Measurements on Wind Turbine Blades in the Field
Program_Area: Atmosphere to electrons: Plant Optimization and Resource Characterization
FOA_Name: Small Technology Transfer Phase I, Release 2
Project_Description:
Increased productivity of wind turbines and wind plants requires a better understanding of the unsteady blade aerodynamics. This understanding could lead to improved energy capture and reduced blade loading and to a better understanding of wake development and propagation that promises to increase the overall production of a wind plant. Unsteady pressure measurements on the surface of the blades of an industrial-scale wind turbine operating in the field would greatly aid in this process. Due to the harsh environments in which wind turbines operate as well as the difficulties inherent in servicing and accessing the blades, a limited number of pressure measurements on full-scale turbines have been conducted. Whereas prior efforts developed pressure measurement systems as part of a larger campaign, this effort specifically focuses on the challenges of unsteady pressure measurements on a wind turbine blade.
It is anticipated that a measurement system specifically tailored to the field environment that addresses its inherent challenges can be designed and manufactured thus allowing easier implementation. Resono Pressure Systems aims to design and manufacture a pressure measurement system capable of being installed on a wind turbine. First, the project will demonstrate a system in the laboratory, which will allow unsteady pressure measurements and will provide the ancillary systems that increase measurement accuracy for extended time periods. There will be a focus on a robust, self-contained system that is capable of long-term operations on a wind turbine blade in a field environment. A user-friendly graphical interface, communication systems, and software for post-processing the raw pressure measurement data will also be developed. Phase 2 would focus on deploying this system on an operational wind turbine to demonstrate its capabilities and to identify any issues that remain to be addressed. Development of a robust pressure measurement system that can be successfully operated in the harsh wind turbine environment would translate to other environmentally and operationally difficult applications. In particular, applications such as environmental wind tunnel testing, helicopter research, flight testing and gas turbine research could utilize such a system to advance the quality of experimental measurements in their respective fields. In addition, improvement in the models used to design wind turbines and wind plants would be possible using the data generated by the proposed system to validate the models, thereby leading to improved predictive capability.

Project_Title: National Offshore Wind R&D Consortium
Awardee: New York State Energy Research and Development Authority
FOA_Name: U.S. Offshore Wind Research and Development Consortium FOA
Project_Description: The offshore wind research and development (R&D) consortium will conduct U.S.-specific research aimed at reducing the cost of offshore wind. The consortium is a cooperative innovation hub, administered by NYSERDA, that will bring in partners from industry and academia to advance offshore wind plant technologies, develop innovative methods for wind resource and site characterization, and develop advanced technology solutions for installation, operation, maintenance, and supply chain – all aimed at reducing the cost of offshore wind in the United States. With only one commercial offshore wind farm operating in the United States, further research is needed to address U.S. specific-conditions. Research will focus on conditions such as deep water where floating foundations are required, areas where the seabed conditions are not well understood, the impact of hurricanes on the East Coast, and challenging environments for installation and operations at sea. All of these challenges require industry-wide collaboration to reduce costs and maximize U.S. economic benefits. DOE is seeding the consortium with $18.5 million, plus providing $2 million to the national laboratories to support consortium R&D activities. All Federal funds will be matched dollar-for-dollar over the lifetime of the consortium.

Project_Title: Big Adaptive Rotor
Project_Description:
For the past few decades, substantial reductions in the cost of wind energy have come from large increases in rotor size. Larger rotors capture substantially more energy, both through a greater swept area and by accessing increased wind speeds at higher above ground levels. For a given nameplate capacity, a larger rotor results in a lower “specific power” (SP) rating, expressed in Watts of capacity per square meter of rotor swept area. All else equal, lower-SP turbines will have higher capacity factors, yielding less variability in power production over time. With limited high wind resource sites remaining, future development will depend in part on deployment in lower wind resource sites, requiring further increases in rotor size for cost-effective energy production. However, the technologies required to enable the next generation of rotors have not been validated, including large blade manufacturing and transportation, rotor controls, aerodynamics, advanced blade materials and structural concepts, and even new blade architectures. In addition, numerous fundamental scientific questions and challenges remain to be solved. The goal of this project is to identify and prioritize needed technology to develop a land-based 5-MW rotor design that achieves a 150 W/meters squared specific power, a 15% increase in plant energy capture, and higher economic value. Project objectives are:
  • Assess trends, impacts, and value of low-SP turbines
  • Screen existing technologies and concepts to determine potential for use in future low-SP turbine designs and technical challenges to their realization
  • Evaluate the current state-of-the-art for conventional off-site manufacturing and transport of large rotor blades, assess alternative options including on-site manufacturing of blades and advances in technologies related to transport and erection, and identify specific areas where further DOE R&D is necessary.
  • Determine optimal process for making carbon fiber for wind blades
  • Perform detailed design studies of selected concepts and undertake scientific investigation of operational environment.
A multi-lab team of SNL, NREL, ORNL, and LBNL are engaged in a five-year integrated research program to develop technology that will drive down the cost of wind energy through increased capacity factors. The National Renewable Energy Laboratory is a co-lead on the project, and is responsible for techno-economic analysis, R&D screening, and system optimization of promising concepts.
