Project_Title: Advanced Lightweight High Efficiency Permanent Magnet Direct Drive Generator for Wind Turbine Applications
Program_Area: Offshore Wind; Next-Generation Technology Development and Manufacturing
FOA_Name: Advanced Next-Generation High-Efficiency Lightweight Wind Turbine Generator FOA
Project_Description:
WEG and partners will design, build and test an advanced permanent magnet direct drive lightweight generator that will be integrated into the existing WEG 4x platform to produce a more competitive product by significantly lowering system mass and cost while increasing energy capture.
WEG will develop the new generator design together with United Technologies Research Center and the National Renewable Energy Laboratory. Starting with WEG's existing 4-MW platform as a baseline, the project team will perform system-level trade studies to identify the most promising generator technologies that will lead to a lower weight, lower cost, and higher efficiency system than is currently available. Following a design and analysis phase and subsequent down-select, this project may be eligible for additional funds to build and test a scaled prototype.

Project_Title: High Efficiency Ultra-Light Superconducting Generator for Offshore Wind
Program_Area: Offshore Wind; Next-Generation Technology Development and Manufacturing
FOA_Name: Advanced Next-Generation High-Efficiency Lightweight Wind Turbine Generator FOA
Project_Description: General Electric (GE) Research of Niskayuna, New York will develop a high-efficiency ultra-light low temperature superconducting (LTS) generator, leveraging innovations from GE’s magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) business. The generator will be tailored for offshore wind and scalable beyond 12 MW. The advantage of LTS generators is the availability of low-cost LTS wire in lengths needed to wind the generator without splices. The challenge with LTS designs is the need to cool the windings to about 4° kelvin, which typically requires the use of liquid helium. Following a design and analysis phase and subsequent down-select, this project may be eligible for additional funds to build and test a scaled prototype.

Project_Title: Advanced Next-Generation High Efficiency Lightweight Wind Turbine Generator
Program_Area: Offshore Wind; Next-Generation Technology Development and Manufacturing
FOA_Name: Advanced Next-Generation High-Efficiency Lightweight Wind Turbine Generator FOA
Project_Description: American Superconductor Corporation of Ayer, Massachusetts will develop a high-efficiency lightweight wind turbine generator that incorporates high-temperature superconductor (HTS) materials to replace permanent magnets in the generator rotor, potentially reducing size and weight by 50%. The advantage of an HTS design is the higher operating temperature of the generator windings, which significantly reduces the challenges associated with maintaining supercritical temperatures in the generator. The challenge with HTS machines is that the winding material is much more expensive, and it comes in relatively short lengths, necessitating many splices. Following a design and analysis phase and subsequent down-select, this project may be eligible for additional funds to build and test a scaled prototype.

Project_Title: Enabling Autonomous Wind Plants through Consensus Control (TCF)
Program_Area: Atmosphere to electrons: Plant Optimization and Resource Characterization
FOA_Name: Technology Commercialization Fund
Project_Description:
Turbines within a wind plant typically operate individually to maximize their own performance without explicitly taking into account information from nearby turbines. Enabling cooperation among turbines to achieve plant-level objectives will allow turbines to use information from other turbines nearby to optimize performance, ensure resiliency when sensors fail, and adapt to changing local conditions. A key element of achieving a more efficient wind plant is to develop and validate algorithms that implement the sharing and fusion of information in a way that is reliable, robust, and can run in real-time for the efficient operation of wind turbines in a wind plant. Such algorithms can use local sensor information that is already being collected, such as supervisory control and data acquisition (SCADA) data, local meteorological stations, and nearby radars/sodars/lidars, in a coordinated way to improve overall operation. 
In this Technology Commercialization Fund project, NREL is working with RES Group to deploy the Collective Consensus Controller for Performance Optimization (C3PO) on a wind plant in the field to demonstrate the potential  power performance gain in wind plants.
Phase 1: Analysis: Provide an analysis of several wind farms across RES’s portfolio to characterize and better understand the benefits and robustness of NREL’s C3PO across different wind farm layouts/sizes, terrain, turbine manufacturers.    
Phase 2: Planning: Determine the additional hardware/software necessary to implement C3PO in an existing wind farm.  
Phase 3: Demonstration: Implement C3PO on a subset of turbines in existing wind farm and collect data to quantify the benefits of a utility-scale wind farm pilot project.

Project_Title: Wind Turbine Drivetrain Reliability Assessment and Remaining Useful Life Prediction (TCF)
FOA_Name: Technology Commercialization Fund
Project_Description:
Due to high O&M cost (up to 30% for offshore wind plants), the wind industry is particularly interested in using turbine prognostics or reliability predictions to answer questions regarding how much remaining useful life (RUL) a turbine and its components have once a fault is detected, and what operational conditions or design shortcomings are causing these components to fail. By doing so, wind plant operators and turbine designers could effectively reduce levelized cost of electricity by optimizing O&M practices, enhancing design, and even augmenting controllers to mitigate damages. There are a few commercial reliability assessment and RUL prediction solution providers, which mainly target classical failure modes, such as bearing rolling contact fatigue, that are not prevalent in the field. Importantly, these commercial packages cannot provide a physical understanding of the leading causes and operational events that have caused reliability issues in the first place. By targeting the most dominant and non-classical gearbox failure mode seen in the field, gearbox bearing axial cracking, NREL has developed reliability assessment and RUL prediction software that uses a physics-domain methodology for gearbox reliability assessment, real-time health monitoring, and RUL predictions. 
The National Renewable Energy Laboratory (NREL) software has successfully identified high-risk operational events for gearbox high speed stage bearing axial cracking failures and can predict future failures months earlier than classical vibration-based methods. Moreover, NREL’s tool fills a gap that the industry has long needed in evaluating the impacts of both normal turbine operations and transient events on turbine component reliability. However, to make the NREL technology widely useful and most beneficial to the wind industry, further validation and maturation of the software are essential. In this Technology Commercialization Fund project, NREL will work with WindESCo, a startup with a dedicated mission to help wind plant owners and operators and the broad industry enhance performance, O&M and lower cost through innovative solutions. WindESCo will provide the needed data to NREL for such technology validation and maturation, and may choose to acquire NREL’s RUL software under an appropriate license, for integration into their commercial solutions for wind industry customers. The validated solutions can be accessed either directly through WindESCo or by licensing with both parties.

Project_Title: Fusion Joining of Thermoplastic Composites Using Energy Efficient Processes (TCF)
FOA_Name: Technology Commercialization Fund
Project_Description: Wind turbine blades are commonly manufactured using thermoset-resin composites in several key components and bonded together with an adhesive. This includes bonding the high- and low- pressure skins at the leading and trailing edge, as well as bonding the shear web and spar caps. Over the life span of a wind turbine, the blades are exposed to structural loads in varying environmental conditions which can lead to cracking and debonding of the adhesive joints, leading to blade structural collapse. Two-part acrylic-based thermoplastic resins can be used as a drop-in replacement for thermoset resins and can be fusion joined (bonded or welded). This Technology Commercialization Fund project led by NREL with GE Global Rsearch will explore the use of fusion joining of thermoplastic wind turbine blades, eliminating the need for adhesives between blade components which could result in stronger and more reliable blades. The use of adhesives to bond wind turbine blades is also a time-consuming manufacturing process. Blade bonding time could be significantly reduced using fusion joining, leading to reduced manufacturing costs. Furthermore, significant weight reductions could be achieved using fusion joining instead of adding heavy adhesives to the blade bond line. Fusion welding can also facilitate blades being manufactured and joined on-site, reducing transportation size limitations and enabling longer blades for increased energy capture. Commercialization of this technology has the potential to result in stronger, less expensive, and longer wind turbine blades, decreasing the levelized cost of electricity and increasing blade reliability, which is critical to advancing the wind energy market.

Project_Title: Evaluation of the Turbine Integrated Mortality Reduction (TIMR) Technology as a Smart Curtailment Approach
FOA_Name: Advanced Wind R&D to Reduce Costs and Environmental Impacts
Project_Description: Electric Power Research Institute (EPRI) will field test their TIMR (Turbine Integrated Mortality Reduction) technology. The technology makes automated decisions to curtail wind turbines based on real-time wind speed, and bat acoustic data against a blanket curtailment regime to compare relative costs and effectiveness.

Project_Title: Developing and Evaluating a Smart Curtailment Strategy Integrated with a Wind Turbine Manufacturer Platform
FOA_Name: Advanced Wind R&D to Reduce Costs and Environmental Impacts
Project_Description: American Wind Wildlife Institute will develop and evaluate a predictive bat risk model that correlates with various environmental and weather variables. The model will be integrated into a smart curtailment program in Vestas’ wind turbine software and will test against blanket curtailment and control turbines.

Project_Title: Activity-based Informed Curtailment: Using Acoustics to Design and Validate Smart Curtailment at Wind Farms
FOA_Name: Advanced Wind R&D to Reduce Costs and Environmental Impacts
Project_Description: Stantec Consulting Services will develop a predictive model that links measured bat risk factors to the effectiveness of smart curtailment regimes at a given wind site.

Project_Title: Evaluating Deterrent Stimuli for Increasing Species-Specific Effectiveness of an Advanced Ultrasonic Acoustic Deterrent
FOA_Name: Advanced Wind R&D to Reduce Costs and Environmental Impacts
Project_Description: The National Renewable Energy Laboratory will improve the effectiveness of the NRG ultrasonic acoustic deterrent. The project will work to improve effectiveness on North American bat species by determining the optimal sound pressure levels, frequencies, and signal patterns for the deterrents through controlled behavioral tests on several bat species.

Project_Title: Ultrasonic Jet Bat Deterrent System Advancement - Research and Large-Scale Validation with Comparisons to Wind Turbine Curtailment
Awardee: General Electric Company through GE Renewable Energy
FOA_Name: Advanced Wind R&D to Reduce Costs and Environmental Impacts
Project_Description: General Electric Company, through GE Renewable Energy will evaluate the relative effectiveness of ultrasonic deterrence versus wind turbine curtailment for different bat species.

Project_Title: Passive Ultrasonic Deterrents to Reduce Bat Mortality in Wind Farms
FOA_Name: Advanced Wind R&D to Reduce Costs and Environmental Impacts
Project_Description: Iowa State University will design a passive, blade-mounted ultrasonic bat deterrent device capable of producing a broad spectrum of ultrasonic tones using a “pipe organ” design.

Project_Title: Coastal Acoustic Buoy for Offshore Wind
Program_Area: Environmental Impacts and Siting; Offshore Wind
FOA_Name: Advanced Wind R&D to Reduce Costs and Environmental Impacts
Project_Description: SMRU Consulting will develop a cost-effective, robust, and reliable network of easily-deployed coastal buoys to monitor North Atlantic Right Whales, and to validate models of noise produced by offshore wind construction activities. The project will validate system effectiveness in the field, including a communications system and software.

Project_Title: Advanced Collision Detection and Site Monitoring for Avian and Bat Species for Offshore Wind Energy
Program_Area: Environmental Impacts and Siting; Offshore Wind
FOA_Name: Advanced Wind R&D to Reduce Costs and Environmental Impacts
Project_Description: Oregon State University will design, build, and test an autonomous monitoring system to accurately detect avian and bat collisions with offshore wind turbines. The system will combine microphones and 360° cameras with analysis software to detect and verify impacts.

Project_Title: A Multi-Sensor Approach for Measuring Bird and Bat Collisions with Offshore Wind Turbines
Program_Area: Environmental Impacts and Siting; Offshore Wind
FOA_Name: Advanced Wind R&D to Reduce Costs and Environmental Impacts
Project_Description: Western EcoSystems Technology, Inc. (WEST) will further develop and test the WT-Bird® bat and bird collision detection system; which combines turbine blade vibration sensors with cameras to quantify impacts.

Project_Title: Second Generation Glass Fiber Composites Fabricated from Retired Wind Turbine Blades
FOA_Name: Small Business Innovation Research Release 2 Phase I
Project_Description: An innovative, energy-neutral process has been developed to repurpose waste from end-of-life wind turbine blades. This process yields recycled materials that are of interest to major industries such as automotive, consumer products, marine, and aerospace industries.

Project_Title: Hybrid Model-based Approach for Remote Diagnostics and Prognostics for Wind Turbines
FOA_Name: Small Business Innovation Research Release 2 Phase I
Project_Description: A key offshore wind technology advancement area identified by DOE's Wind Energy Technologies Office relates to Installation, operations and maintenance, and supply chain technology solutions.  Through this SBIR project, Qualtech Systems striving to address the O&M aspect of this vision by lowering the O&M costs of running an offshore and land based wind turbines.
